editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A SURVEY OF THE WORLD. IN TEN BOOKS
BY BARTEN HOLYDAY D. D. And Archdeacon of OXFORD.
OXFORD, Printed by Will. Hall, for the Authour.

div.head: TO The Worthily Honour'd, the Vertuous and Learned Sr. RICHARD BROWN, Knight and Baronet, one of the Clerkes of his MAJESTIE'S Moſt Honourable Privy Council.
div.p:
THe Remembrance of Just Delight delights; which as it is an acknowledg'd Truth in Nature; ſo eſpecially in the nature of knowledge. This at this time of Joy and Happineſſe for our Returne to theſe bleſſings, under our greateſt bleſſing, our moſt gratious Soveraigne, aptly prompts to a Repetition of thoſe Studies, to which the Love and Prudence of your Eminent Father promoted your Youth and my Induſtry about fourty years ſince, in your Academical Inſtitution. The Improvement whereof as your Wiſdome has ſhowed in additions of Perſevering Loyally, weighty Employment and Nineteen Years Abſence from your dear Country: So in the Importunity of the late warres and opinions, ſome addition, I have made of After-ſtudies in the defence of Religion and Arts. With a neceſſary variety therefore from the ſingularities of the Divine Power and Wiſdome, I heere preſent the Thea
•• er of Providence, in ſome things ſtrange, in All warrantable, by teſtimony of Men famous among Heathens
and Chriſtians. Which diligence may bee to ſome a Direction for Choiſe and Cenſure; to Others no uncourteou •• Recollection of their Owne Thoughts. And as they were a Summer's recreations of my Age, caſt thus into the Faſhion of Ancient Memorials; ſo I intend them not as a Laborious Summe of knowledge; but only, as in the Liberty and Pleaſure of a garden, as ſome more; pleaſing flowers cropp'd for the Complement and Enchridion 〈◊〉 a Poſy: which by the Novelty may laſt a Day, and by the Art of Friendſhip, may, as Friendſhip ſhould, outla •• the vanity of the Flower. Yet as this pleaſes by Intermiſſion, the ſeeming Neglect renewing the delight, I but preſent, not obirude, to the leaſure of Your great affaires, reſpectfully remaining.

closer.signed: Noble Sr. The Glad Obſerver Of Your Choiſe Accompliſhments And Eminent Merits, BARTEN HOLYDAY.

div.head: To the Studious Reader.
div.l: AS weary travelour that climbes a Hill,
Lookes back, ſitts down, and oft, if hand have ſkill,
Landſkippes the Vale with pencil; placing here
Medow, there Arable, here Foreſt, there
A Grove, a City, or a Silver-ſtreame,
As offring to yield beauty to his Scheme;
Then decks it for the Gallery, and Views
If th' Eye and Phanſy count it Pleaſing News:
So now my Thoughts and Hopes, that long have climb'd
Learning's Aſcents, by which True Art's ſublim'd,
Turne, Reſt, and their owne wandrings View. Here Light
They ſee, by which they ſee; there deepeſt Night,
The World's New Chaös: here a tinſell'd Sky,
That does with beauty pleaſe and poſe the Eye;
There Earth, Beaſt, Fowle, Myſtical Man, whoſe braine,
A leſſe World, would the greater world containe,
Theſe, if by Nature's Herald, Art, well plac'd,
Preſent Nature and Art by Union grac'd.
To view which, no new Alpes wee need, whoſe height
Shows Europe's dreſs, which Thence may 't Pleaſe, or Fright?
Wee need no Ararat to ſhow Aſian Glory,
It ſelfe having Ark'd-up rich Aſia's ſtory.
No Atlas need wee, Africa's proud eye,
The Myſteries of its Deſerts to diſcry.
The New world's Andes wee can wiſely ſpare:
The proſpect there, but not quick death, is rare.
Wee need no Tenariffa, which does ſhoote
So high, my eye J'de lend it, not my foot.
No cunning mountaine need wee, whence the Devil
Would ſhow the whole world's Glory, not the Evil:
Fear'd hee 't would ſpoile his Bribe? But here below
From Art, not Mountaine, Truth enough wee ſhow.
If then thy Eye venters to bee ſo kind,
Scone View the Long View of a Searching Mind.

div.head: The ARGUMENTS Of The Several Books.

lg.l: THe Heav'n is Arch; Therefore it ſelfe Suſtaines:
The Earth is Center; Therefore So Remaines:
• he World's a Priſon; no man can get out:
• et th' Atheiſt ſtorme then; 't is Heav'n round about.
• eav'n is the Silke-worme's Spheare: what Art did ſpinne it
• oes at its pleaſure chooſe to dwell within it.
• ow bleſt was Steph'n, whoſe eje Heav'n did permi •
• o ſee, who does at th' Father's right hand ſit!

Was Paul more happy at the Third Heav'n •
ſight
• r more Tormented to Delay Delight?
Who firſt Mov'd Heav'n, Philoſopher's halfe-ſkill
• nquir'd: 'T was Hee, that made the Sunne ſtand ſtill.
〈◊〉 weight from the Ninth Spheare Ninety yeares ſpends,
• y two hundred miles an howr, e're't quite Deſcends!
• f Man Aſcended ſtill tow'rd the High'ſt ſpheare,
• ight thouſand yeares hee'd ſpend, e're hee were There!
• he white and yelke are cloſures in a ſhell:
Art thus makes Orbes kindly in Orbes to dwell.
Though Many Heav'ns wee thinke there are below
The High'ſt: to This by Thoſe faire ſtepps wee goe.
The Low'ſt Aſcents in Heav'n have each their Light:
The Next is Fill'd with ſtarres; No point is Night.
The Starry Heav'n, which Divine power ſo paints,
In Figure ſhews th' Aſſembly of the Saints.
Saturne, next the fix'd ſtarres, wiſe death may preach:
Thoughts muſt bee ſober, that think Heav'n to reach.
Jove was in Fiction Joy: but in the Skie
'Tis the next ſtep to Saturne's Gravitic.
A Heav'nly Mars, what is't, but a ſtour hand,
Againſt the Dragon, in Saint Michael's Band?
The Sunne is a Great Light to all eyes free:
And yet Heav'n's Greateſt Light wee cannot ſee.
The Hurry of the Sunne in his Owne Spheare,
That meaſures Thriſe five Miles each Minute Heere!
Seemes not the Sunne, for Speed of courſe, to merit
The name, not of a Body, but a Spirit?
Copernicus will have the Sunne ſtand ſtill,
To ſcape doubts: Hee makes New! This is New skill!
Some New Astronomers in the Sunne find Spots:
Heav'n was nere Curs'd: The Sunne's Light knows no Elot!
Some find of late New ſtarres about the Sunne!
Needs hee more light? God's work with wiſdome's donne!
Venus in Heav'n muſt needs bee Faire and Pure:
• f it Invites, it mocks, the Epicure.
• ſercurie's Witt and Tongue doe plainly tell
The Witt and Tongue find place in Heaven, us'd well.
The Moone is the World's Glaſſe, in which, 't were ſtrange,
• f wee ſaw Hers, and ſaw not our Owne Change!
The learned Fa • er has the Journy meaſur'd
Up to the Moone: ſure, wiſe men he has pleaſur'd.
News from the Moone; 't is told by very Fame,
There's a ſtrange Man, from Adam that ne're came!
Galilie in the Moone finds yet more Change:
The Man i' th' Moon, once Tale, ſeems Truth! That's ſtrange!
Traſfique to th' Moone! Is't done by art of Wing?
To Aſcend, prov'd Chriſt God! what proves this New thing?
Who'll flie to Heaven, muſt ſtore of Vict' alls keepe!
And ſometimes muſt at once both Flie and ſleepe!
Some think the Starres Holes, through which Heav'n ſends Light:
Then into Heav'n might not aſcend Our night?
Some thinke the Earth a starre: then ſhould it Light
Send forth abroad upon the Heav'n by Night.
Th' Arabians will the Starres like Letters ſpell;
But who did e're Demonſtrate what they tell?
Experience oft Pretends, not ſo True Art:
That may miſtake; from Truth This does not ſtart.
Fore-knowledge is Divine; Man's Witt Ambitious:
What's Hali, Nabod, Bonat, Alcabitius?
Goate-witted Man to climbe will venter, if
Hee may; though hee hangs by th' claws againſt a cliffe!
The Art of ſtarres who knows, but Hee that made them?
But Man's bold Gheſſe, to God's wrong, would invade them.
To found an Art on Figurative Grounds,
Reaſon without true Art ſondly confounds.
What though, to worke on Earth, the Starres Indeavour;
Since what's receiv'd is chang'd by the Receivour?
What though the Starres with lower cauſes cloſe,
If in Man's Actions Grace does Interpoſe?
The Milky Way which does the Heaven imbrace,
Shews, Men of Small Light may in Heaven find place;
The Milky Way muſt with the ſtarres bee rang'd:
What's out of Heav'n continues not Unchang'd.
Light, what it is, does Senſe, nay Wit, well know?
Light is ſcarce light enough, it ſelfe to ſhew.
The World's a picture; Light at firſt was hurld
Upon't: Is it God's ſhadow in the world?
The Fire next Heav'n's like zeale; but not ſo Cruel;
• t Burnes, yet not Devours: 't is its Own Fuel.
Th' Aire's Higheſt Region's Hot; Cold in the Middle;
The Low'ſt by Reflexe Warme: See Nature's Riddle!
Thunder preſents God's Majeſty to th' Eare;
Which is the Gate of Faith and Holy Feare!
When Heare and Cold, met in the ſame cloud, jolt;
The Thunder's Sentence! Guilt's the Thunder-bolt!
When, on Mount Sinai, Thunders loud did roare,
They ſhooke the Mount, and th' Holy Cloud they toare.
One moſt ſtrange Meteor has it ſelfe renound,
The Sinai-Trumpet, which it ſelfe did ſound!
At the Last-Day, when all things down are hurl'd,
Jehovah's Voice ſhall Trumpet-up the World!
Lightning Appeares firſt: Thunder's firſt: The Eie
Of Conſcience ſees Guilt, before Judgment's Nigh!
Lightning, the Mother Sav'd, the Child within
Has kill'd! The Soule ſav'd, Conſcience ſo kills Sinne!
A Comet, is't the Carbuncle of Sinne,
Maſs'd-up from th' Earth and Hell, whence 't did begin?
How at a Comet ev'ry one does ſtare?
When many, who thus Gaze, worſe Comets are!
Who Many Sunnes ſees, ſees not his Abuſe;
Unleſſe of his Miſtake hee makes more Uſe.
Clammy Smoakes Fir'd and Falling ſtarres ſome call:
Their phanſie erres; Truth from their witt does fall.
The Fooliſh Fire oft, that by night does move,
Does by Miſtake or Feare, Focles make or prove.
What Bluſtring, Hott, Thick Aire's This? 'Tis the Wind;
Faint Embleme yet of Man's more Troubleſome Mind!
Whirle Wind, th' art a Surprize! Nothing's like Thee
But Rapture, from the Spirit of Propheſie!
Raine's Cloud Diſſolv'd: Thus from the Law, Sad Feares.
By warmth of grace, deſcend in fruitfull Teares!
• y Red, Green, Blew, which ſometimes paint the Aire,
• uilt, Pardon, Heav'n, the Raine-bow does declare.
The Raine-bow to the Sunne yields due reſpect:
• race, the Soule's beauty, does to God Reflect.
When Heav'n rain'd Clouds, and did Our World confound;
The Aire ranne Chanel, and All Seas were Drown'd!
• ome make Dutch Schuarts Founder of Gunnes and Shot:
The Volly of Haile and th' Amorites they forgot.
Th' Earth through great Heat, Cold, Wind, Dew oft does lacke:
• y Luſt, Deſpaire and Rage, Grace is kept-backe.
Hoare-Froſt, a Dew congeal'd, on high Hills ne're
• s found: Preſumption unacquainted is with Feare.
Snow is a Cloud, Light, but congeal'd: Grace Join'd
With Doubt, may knowledge, yet leſſe Comfort, find.
At the laſt Day ſhall the Saints Meteors bee?
Their Earth ſublim'd ſhall yet from Change bee Free!
Sea is the Earth of Water: The ſunne draines
What's pure ſ • om Groſſe: Sea, that is, Salt, remaines.
The Sea is ſalt; Salt's Wiſdome: That can reare
The weight of ſhippe; This the world's burden beare.
It is the Moone's Increaſe, that ſwells the Ocean:
'Tis the Firſt mover ſhews the Way o'th motion.
Vanity does too oft man's large Mind fill:
But the Firſt mover Guides th'obedient will.
River is Time in Water: as it came,
Still ſo it flowes; yet never is the ſame.
Some think th'Earth ſtarre: Indeed ſtarres ſend forth Beams.
Wee'll call it Heav'n; the Springs ſo ſend forth ſtreams.
Shoot up an arrow, not farre off 'tis found:
Moves th'Earth then ſwift enough, if it turnes round?
Shall not the Aire turne faster then the Earth?
To think it moves not ſo, is't Truth, or Mirth?
Wonders we have on Earth; thus wee may know
What things there are Above, by what's Below.
Clay, Sand and Rocke, ſeem of a diff'rent birth:
So men; ſome Stiffe, ſome Looſe, ſome Firme: All Earth!
Downe Picke-axe, to the Depth for Gold lets goe:
Wee'll undermine Pe • u: Is'nt Heav'n Below?
Quick-ſilver, Nature's Jugler's Many in One:
Now it is Fix'd: Now 'tis Looſe: now 'tis Gone!
Quick-ſilver Conſcience, play not Faſt and Looſe:
Faſt will the Looſe bee, to it's Owne Abuſe!
Marble, a ſtately Vanity, does ſhow,
In Natur's A ••• , Spots doe for Beauty goe.
Each Duſt Loadſtone has two points: 't will riſe
To th' Loadſotone: Many at once may fright our eyes!
Why ſhould the world the Diamond ſo commend?
This Conſtant is: the World's a Crumbling friend.
The Emerald's the Ey's Favorite: wee doe
In One find the Object and Spectacle too.
The Ruby is an Earth, and yet a Fire:
A Holy Man! What Earth to Heav'n comes Nigher?
The Margarite's compos'd of Heavenly Dew:
Heav'n is the Pearle, that is prepar'd for Few!
Cedar the Dead from Putreſaction keepes:
The juſt more ſafely in Chriſt's merits ſleepes.
The Oake beares Fruite, though Bloſſome it beares none:
The juſt beares fruite, though of it is not knowne.
The Olive loves Hot ground, not fat, nor leane:
Grace is the Juſt Man's Joy, in ſtate though Meane.
The Serpent ſhunnes the Odour of the Vine:
A Venom'd Soule flies from the Sacred Wine.
The Laurell's a perpetual Green: wee may
See Grace thus flouriſh. Grace is its owne Bay.
By whom ſhall Cinnamon's praiſe bee fully Chanted?
'Tis as Reſtorative, as Deſire Granted!
The Corne, the Graſſe, for Man, for Beaſt, renew:
God teaches them to Feed and Teach us too.
Courſe wonder, Garlicke! Begger's Galen! Wiſe
Thy Clownes are: Noſe-coy fooles thy Wit Deſpiſe.
The Pinke by Nature's ſo refin'd, wee dare
Allmoſt to aske, whither't is Flow'r, or Aire.
The Violet, the Flow'r of Courteſie, Delight
Does yeild unto the Touch, Taſt, Smell and Sight.
The Roſe is but the Flower of a Brier:
The Good man has an Adam to his Sire.
What's Beauty without Vertue, but the Lilie?
Faire to the Eye; the ſent will quickly fill yee.
To weed the Garden pleaſure prompts ſome Care:
To weed the Mind, ſhall ſafety no time ſpare?
WHo can Acres of Whale, in the Ocean See,
And with's Owne wonder, not Aſtoniſh'd bee?
To ſee Nine hundred foote of Whale, may make
One thinke, Iland for Fiſh hee does miſtake.
The Whale, a Live Sea, Jonah did incloſe:
Were Night, Feare, Grave and Hell at once his foes?
Jonah found Aire in water: though command
Freedome he could not; did he not find Land?
Woder in Wonder doe the Sea-men note:
The Whale's vaſt bulke has but a narrow throate.
What's great Leviathan, that does turmoile
Himſelfe ſo much in Wave, but Bone and Oile?
Oile makes the wool run in the Cards the better:
Sathan's glibbe arts make Man to Grace more debter.
Though the Whale's Bone finds uſe too much about us,
Yet Grace and Wit keep the Devil and that without us.
The Whale's Mouth's a Portcullis, but Inverted?
Th' under jaw's Teeth into Holes above inſerted.
O Man take heed of Hell: if that once Swallow,
Leviathan does ſhew thee, what does follow!
The Greene-Land Sea's the world: with happy Gale
And Art of grace, lets maſter the Great Whale!
Out with your barrels, Sailours, the Whale's neere:
Upon another point inſtantly ſteere.
A black beaſt with ſquare head, fiery eyes, 't is Tradition,
Iſland-Seas ſhow: Is't Fiſh, or apparition!
The Cuttle-Fiſh with's Inke the Sea does ſtaine:
His Witt's his Veile: A ſearch is then but vaine.
The Rémora a ſhippe's courſe ſtopps ſome ſay:
The Dev'l indeed our Chriſtian courſe would ſtay.
The Crampe-fiſh does the Fiſher catch: his hand
Hee ſtupifies: Thus Craft 'gainſt Craft does band.
Polonians to Revenge doe not more thronge,
Then Dolphins ſhoale it, if you doe them wrong.
A Porpiſe, the Sea-Almanack, fore-ſhows
A Storme: Hee's happy that worſe ſtormes fore-knows.
Shrimp • , Sea-Elixir. though thy Circle's ſmall,
Thou art to man Food, Temperance, Life and all.
The Prince of Feaſts, the Sturgeon, does command
The Ghueſts: Th' Obey, that think they underſtand.
The Dainty Salmon Courtier of the Seas,
With Temperance is pleaſure; els Diſeaſe.
Why ſhould the backward Crabbe bee ſo aſham'd!
They rather that Abuſe him ſhould bee Blam'd.
Lobster, the warmth of Age, is but Repaire;
'Tis but Abus'd, when Us'd for prouder fare.
Lamprey is Danger; ſtomach is but Coy;
Pleas'd you may bee; you may your ſelfe Annoy.
Nine times an Eele through a Cormorant has paſs'd.
E're kild: A ſlipp'ry Sinner's caught at laſt.
The Seale, the Pike, the Perch, though fiſh, wee muſt
For true repaire, call fleſh: 't were els Unjuſt.
The Gudgeon is the tender ſtomach's meat
And Sauſe: of this the Rich and Poore may eat.
The Trout repreſſes Choler: what is Coole.
Hot, Moift, or Drie, in fare; ſhould bee our Schoole.
Fiſh ſpeake God's Love and Wiſdome, without Voice:
All's not for All; but Some for All with Choiſe.
The Sharke, the Otter, Vexe the Sea and River:
What Sanctuary can Man ſtill deliver?
The Dying Moale, ſay ſome, Opens his eyes:
The Rich, till 'tis too late, will not be wiſe.
The Worme Lives in his Grave: Doe what he can,
He's but a worme. No muck-worme is a Man.
To Heav'n a Soule ſome Old Philoſophy gives:
On Earth the Gloow-worme is a Starre, and Lives.
See the Ant's Mountaine! Babel's Tow'r againe?
Heere's as much Bus'neſſe! Though't is not ſo Vaine.
What Seeds th' Ant Stores, he Bites: what Grows, hee Looſe
Scarce ſhall he grow, whom a Grand Politique Uſes.
The Spider builds in Palaces; Her owne
Is webbe: i' th' midſt whereof ſhee's Queen Alone.
To One man's peace, the Spider's Wiſdome ſhows,
An Other man his peace oft wiſely Owes.
Flies oft remov'd returne: Doe they want Feare,
Or Shame, or Memory? Flies are ev'ry where.
A dried Toad layd nigh th' Heart, ſtays blood: wee have
Sinne, which if layd to Heart, the Soule may ſave.
The Flea, that feeds on Duſt and Blood, not long
Triumphs; Hee's Snapp'd: Such is the end of Wrong!
The Gnat is the poore man's Revenge: Hee brings
• mall ſtrength; yet makes great noiſe, and ſhrewdly ſtings.
What in the flow'r is found moſt pure and Sweet,
That only for his Combe the Bee thinks meet!
The Monarch Bee, when feeble, by the reſt
• s carried: So Jrrev'rence they deteſt.
Whole pits with Hony in Lithuania flow:
• uge Beares are Choak'd in it; Pleaſure's a Foe!
The Silke-worme's its owne wonder, without Loome
• t does provide it ſelfe a ſilken roome.
The Silke-worme's Nature's Poet, who excels
• n phanſie, in whoſe Court with Art hee dwels.
See how the Eagle mounts tow'rds Heav'n: Hee's gone
Quire out of ſight; Right Embleme of Saint John!
Brave bird of Thunder! Capaneus was Fable:
'Tis th' Eagle Dares breaſt Lightning, and ſeemes Able.
Eagle and Lightning met, in juſt account,
May make us thinke, wee ſee Eliah mount.
In th' Eagle's Eye ſee th' Eye of Juſtice, fierce
Both ſeeme, and, what they view, they deepely pierce.
Th' Eagle's Thigh does the Lion's thigh Out-waigh!
Is's not a Bird of an Imperial Sway?
The Eagle to the Sunne preſents his yong:
Is't Bold? Hee Owns't: Aoe • 't Turne? Away't is flung.
Mount, O my Soule, and to thy maker bring
Thy loſtieſt Thoughts, his Gift, with Soaring Wing!
Deſcend, My Soule, ſometimes, but to repaire
Strength for New Flight into Diſcov'ring Aire.
The Eagle caſts his Bill, and becomes New:
Oh, may my Soule find but a Change as true!
The Vultur will draw blood from his Owne thigh,
If hee wants Prey! Herodian Cruelty!
Man, haſt thou Grace? Th' haſt Sinne! See, 'tis but Meet
Not only the Swan's Feathers, but his Feet.
Pride can not ſee it ſelfe by Mid-day-light: l
The Peacocke's Taile is Fartheſt from his Sight!
A Parrot learn'd the Creed: may not ſuch, greeve,
As can not ſay't, or can not it Beleeve?
The Nightingale's a Quire, no Single Note:
O Various pow'r of God in One ſmall Throate!
The Cuckow's but Two Notes: what Artiſt tells
The Cauſe? Or why the Nightingale excels?
The Cuckow's Halſe an Owle; Hee flies Man's fight:
The Owle, a double Cuckow, flies by Night.
Wonder it ſees, where ſo e're the Eye does Rowle:
The Batt is the Aire-Mouſe; The Night's his Hole.
The Swallow's a Quicke Arrow, that may ſhow
With what an Inſtant Swif • neſſe Life does flow.
Though the Cocke's Muſique from his Vigour bee,
• an is left pos'd: The full cauſe can hee ſee?
• eeſe Sav'd Rome's Capitol, the Cocke Saint Peter:
• o a wiſe Mind his Muſique's ſure the ſweeter.
• er Yong the Pidgeon firſt with Salt-earth feeds:
• iſe Education thus a wiſe man breeds.
With what a Roare of Fury Lions rage?
'Tis Halfe a Fright, to ſee the Lions Cage!
That doe wee talke of Wild beaſts more then One?
The Lion is a Wilderneſſe Alone!
The Lion vex'd, with taile ſtrikes th' Earth; Next blow
• ates his Owne Back: The Laſt Confounds his Foe.
The Ly • ian Lion eates Man, Woman, Child:
Eates Him; Then Them: His Hunger's wiſely Mild!
The Leopard's ſo ſtrong, ſo Quicke, ſo Fierce;
As if, whiles Nam'd, hee'd Leape too in the Verſe.
As from the Tiger ſwift and fierce wee'd runne:
With greater Care our greateſt Foe lets ſhunne.
Cruell's the Beare, h' has yet but a weake head;
A blow has kild him: by Chriſt's Death Sinne's Dead.
Th' Arabian Fox robbes Houſes, and ſteales Shooes:
Our Foe would us ſpiritually ſo abuſe.
The Rav'nous Wolfe will feed on Mice and Moles:
Sathan does thus devoure darke Earthy ſoules!
O mocke of Pride! Man can not Change his Shape:
Though, whiles unchang'd, hee is but like an Ape.
The ſhifting Heare wee pitty; ſcorne the Hart;
To flie when Arm'd, is but the Coward's part.
The Sicke Hart eates a Snake, and ſo grows well:
Repentance Digeſts Sinne, and Man ſcapes Hell.
Much 't is the Afrique Camels Long can faſt:
More, that they Inceſt Hate, admir'dly chaſt!
• normous Excellency! Th' Elephant
Nor ſtrength, nor wit, nor words, ſome ſay, does want!
• n the Elephant's Heart is found a mighty Bone:
Inhappy Man, whoſe Heart is oft All ſtone!
The Aſſe for Burden, as the Horſe for Speed,
God has giv'n Man, Man's Double helpe at need.
Th' Aegyptian thought the Dog a God! Hee might
Take him a Friend: Hee's Safty or delight.
Glutton-Jew of all men was moſt croſs'd:
The various dainties of the Hogge hee loſt.
The Cow yields milke; the Sheepe cloths: both are good,
Thus both Alive; and when Both Dead, th' are Food.
The Catt's Eye's Providence, It Sees by Night:
〈◊〉 Guard of Angels yields both Joy and Might.
• ore Life to Man, then to the Crow God gives:
• ong lives the Crow: Man lives, and Dies, and Lives!
• an's Braine is Curds and Wonder! Truth this cleares:
• athuſhelah's was unchang'd nine hundred years!
Blood Circles from the Heart unto the Heart:
• an's New America ſpeakes Harvie's Art!
I' Wake and ſo new Live: a Night's Protection
Is a new Wonder, whiles a Reſurrection.
I' Wake and too too ſoone my Thoughts begin
To ſtray: Can Sleepe halfe-Reſcue us from Sinne?
The Sunne's up: yet My ſelfe and God moſt bright
I can't ſee: J'me too Darke, and Hee's too Light!
Cloths, which Hide ſhame, ſhame us, ſinne they preſent:
Wee're Cloth'd yet in the Grave, when Innocent!
Hand, waſh thy fellow; yet the waſhing's vaine:
Wee are Sinne's Black-Moores, though wee waſh againe.
Let devout Prayer caſt me to the Ground:
So ſhall I yet to Heaven bee Neerer found.
What ſhall I Doe to day? I pray'd to ſhunne
All Sinne; but, from my Prayer 'tis, I runne.
Hunger ſays, Feed: Feed? ſays Temperance;
Through Food, Sloth, Sleepe and Luſt, Life's but a Dance.
The Holy Book is my Receite; a Sure
Cordial, a Pow'rful Trouble, and a Cure.
Advance My Taſke, Thy Praiſe, Spirit Divine!
I'le Slight the Aide then of Poëtique Wine!
TIs Morning; therefore Night; This Order keepes
The world: ſtill One Halfe wakes; the Other Sleepes.
• ow Nations fill the Earth, like Diff'rent Seeds!
•• ch Country unlike Men and Manners breeds!
• he Spanjard's Sober, Wiſe, Conſtant, Devout;
〈◊〉 Avarice, Pride, Luſt, Blood! Th' Indian cri'd out!
• aine's the Third Indies; Spice and Gold it ſleights:
〈◊〉 Deeper Mines of Counſaile it delights.
〈◊〉 the French, wine of Orleans? Flame, Wounds, Scarres?
•• ates hee the Chronicle by Civil warres?
• h' Italian's the World's Gentleman; A Court!
• o which, Thrift, Witt, Luſt and Revenge reſort.
• hey erre, who Rome's Hills by the Old names call:
• he Vatican is now the Capitol.
• alie's Church is Rome; Naples the Court:
• ononia the Great Schoole; Venice the Port.
• ame does for wiſdome Venice highly reare:
• he Turke ſuſpects, their Wiſdome is Halfe Feare.
• ybaris once for Vice was the World's Blot:
• he World's a ſtaine! Sybaris now's no Spot.
When from the Alpes the Afrique-General
View'd Italy, their Top was Hannibal.
Britans, yee are ſtout men; bee alſo wiſe:
They'd need bee ſo, on whom are all mens eyes.
Faſhions and Propheſies are England's ſtaine:
Lets not bee Mad too, though wee have been vaine.
Bogges, Purgatory, Wolves and Eaſe, by Fame
Are counted Ir'land's Earth, Miſtake, Curſe, Shame.
Earthquake is ſcarce acquainted with Scotch Ground:
Yet many Jolts of State have There been found.
The Belgian's the World's Scout: Water's his Land:
His Fleete's his Country; and his Art's his Hand.
The Portly Alman, if wine ſays not Nay,
Beares his Head high, as if his head bare ſway.
Of Daniſh kings Chriſtian's a Name and Riches,
Could they make Chriſtians of their Norway-Witches.
Whom more then the Firſt Suede did Fame e're cloy?
This made Lutzen more Griefe, then His Life Joy.
Ruſſia is wilderneſs; the Man is Furre:
Thatch is his Houſe; his Winter's One Long Murre.
Againſt his Owne Foes the Polonian's bold:
〈◊〉 Gainſt Heav'n's has his Owne Winter been more Cold?
Can the Racovian thinke troubles can ceaſe,
• f with Socinus God's Foe hee's in peace?
Hungarie's king is alſo Damocles:
His Right gives Throne; th' Impendent Sword no Eaſe?
Th' Old Greeke was Mirth and Wine; now wretched feares
May make him drinke in Silence his own teares!
The Turke ſells Liberty! The Turke does prize it
Though't's Above price! The pooreſt Gre • ke yet Buyes it!
The Owle, Athens held Sacred: ſure a ſoule
Miſtake of phanſy! Athens was the Owle!
Th' Athenian Wit ſcorn'd to bee Paul's Witt's Debter:
• uſt Paul n'ere grac'd th' Athenians with a Letter!
Candie's the Chriſtian Weere: the Seas oft racke
Amaine, from Helleſpont: yet oft rowle backe.
The Turke's Mad to bee Mad: Hee's a Darke Mind:
Which can no Heav'n, but his Owne Body, find.
To Homer's Muſe, but firſt to its Owne ſhame
And Ruine, Troy owes its Unhappy Fame!
Caeſar once thought to make Troy a New Rome:
Byſanti • um got the Name; Hee got a Tombe!
A ſtately Shrine the Dev'l at Epheſus
Did raiſe: he would ſupply a Loſt Heav'n Thus!
Paradiſe o're Granada hangs; Spaine boaſts!
But Heav'n Saint John ſaw, o're the Pathmian Coaſts!
When Iſrael Canaan left; Canaan became
Aegypt: but Goſhen got Canaan's Fame.
Old Salem Longer was, then broad; though Faire:
But New Ieruſalem's a perfect Square.
God's Temple was Earth's Heav'n, yet Heaven he bow'd:
Came downe, and dwelt in Myſtery and Cloud.
Arabia once was happy: Now what's Left,
But Sottiſh Mecha, Wilderneſſe and Theft?
When God dwelt forty years midſt Rockes and Sand,
Was not the Wilderneſſe a Holy Land?
Babel was Nebuchadnezzar! at leaſt
In pride! In Judgment too! 'Tis very Beaſt!
Babel's proud walls, that were an Army, Now
By turnes do to the Turke and Perſian bow.
The Perſian Dwells on Horſe-back: Surely Hee
Was the Right Centaure in Old Poëtry.
The Tartar, Nature's Heretique, Roaves in State:
Hee's a Land-Planet; or, what ſome call Fate.
India's the World's Faire: Gold, Spice, Gemmes, d' yee want •
They're There; the Carrier too, the Elephant.
With Silkes and phanſies th' Eaſt the world does fill:
How farre wee faile to pleaſe but our Owne Will?
The China-Anchorets Wall'd-up did dwell;
The Snaile was not more faithful to his ſhell.
Amboina's Spices doe the Body warme:
But Got by violence doe the Soule more harme.
Ormuz, Eye of the Sea, if thou 'dſt ſhine bright,
• hine with a Chriſtian Chriſtalline, thou 'lt ſhine right.
Aloes from Zocatrà who but procures
• or Health? Bitter Repentance who Indures?
When God to Sheba wiſdome did unfold,
〈◊〉 ſent him its Firſt wiſdome, Spice and Gold.
The Sheba-Queene, who mov'd by Solomon's fame,
• ame to bee wiſe, was wiſe before ſhee came.
Th' Abiſſine-Child Baptis'd in Fire may ſtart:
Growne Man, a fire hee muſt have in his Heart.
Mountaines o' th' Moone wee heare of; whoſe Foote's 〈◊〉
Whoſe Top is Heav'n! who'll then a fall There Vent •
Earth in the Moon has Galilaeus found?
The Mountaines of the Moone are ſurer ground.
Nilus is Aegypt's Almanack, prevailes
To fore-tell ſtore; how s' ere the Starres-Man faile's.
When Aegypt's king God's word Tranſlated ſhoud,
Sure thrice five Cubits then Nilus oreflow'd!
Vaſt and Full Cair, if Fame does not beguile us,
Th' art Double-ſtor'd: Thy People is a Nilus!
Thy Founder, Alexandria, makes thee ſtory:
Thy Athanaſius is thy Greateſt glory.
Who thinks Cyréne Barren, his Witt's Groſſe:
It brought forth Simon, who did beare Chriſt's Croſſe.
Carthage and Rome did once each other feare:

But Auſtin's Hipp •
conquerd both; 'tis Cleare.
Great Hannibal, bee 't ſet upon thy tombe:
Treacherous Carthage was great Hannibal's Rome!
Who thinkes Algier's Holy, ſurely beleeves
〈◊〉 Howſe of Pray'r's ſometimes a Denne of Theeves.
• oledo's prelate wonne Oràn to Spaine
• nd Chriſt: a Two-edg'd Sword's a Double gaine.
• ez wonder is: a Building without Ground!
• oſchees and Hoſpitals, where no Faith's found!
• ez obſerves Mahomet's Birth-day: Verſe does flow!
• hall wee doe leſſe for Christ, who more doe Owe?
• arocco's Tow'r three Globe of Gold, moſt faire
• or Art and Weight, grace: 'Tis a Mine i' th' Aire!
• hree Silver-Globes ſurmount Marocco's Spire
• lmanſor's worth above them yet mounts Higher.
•• midia's ſand and wild Beaſt! Is ought worſe?
• he Mankind of the Country is the Curſe!
〈◊〉 way to Atlas, you whom Luſt does pleaſe:
• h' Aire cures, though not the Soule, the Ranke Diſeaſe.
• lia, thy Lions like Thy Sunne-beames rage:
• unger and Flame more eaſy 't is to' ſwage.
• abia once Christian was; ſure Arian too!
• he Rankeſt poiſon's There, that e're man knew.
The Ʋnknowne Lands' i' th' South; your Mappe-men ſay:
It is as well i' the Midſt of Africa.
Congoant, when Heathen, made their Foe their Meat:
Now no man, but their friend, by Faith they eate.
Angola Slaves, for gaine, once joint-meat ſold'
Could Nature bee unnatural, though Bold?
Why are Some Negros? Did it firſt proceed
From proper Situation? Now, from Breed?
The Guinean fires his houſe, when Warres begin!
In Holy warfare could wee ſo leave Sinne!
Canarie's grape was in the Portugall's power;
Xerez in Spaine's: Has Spaine now Sweete and Sowre!
Had Teneriffa • s top by th' Arke been found,
Would then the Babel-men have raiſd their ground?
Tow'rds Africa a Sea of Weeds wee have:
Is't not the picture of the World in wave?
Stranger, would'ſt Die? Saint Thomas-Iland ſee:
By Fifty, Nature's Jubily ſets thee free.
On Good Hope's Cape ſeemes there a Paradice Spred!
Fruit There Man eat; with raw guts Heere they're fed!
• f Wiſdome may diſcover; Speed and Way
May make us thinke, Ophir was Sofalà.
Deſtroy the World's ſtore, and but Zeilan ſpare,
May n't wee from Thence (D' yee doubt?) the World repaire?
• eas Cement Lands: did then by th' Art of Boate
Croſſe th' Anyan Ferry World to World firſt floate?
The South-Eaſt Ilands did New Guiny fill:
Might they not teach Fogo Like Love and Skill?
Mayre's ſtraights and Magellan's Fogoans paſſe-over:
Three times as farre from Calice 't is to Dover.
Magellan Gyants doe like Canon, roare:
• ure then they need no Beacons on the ſhoare.
Perù's a Land of promiſe: is 't ſo Holy?
• t Tempts; yet ſome, for Gold, find their owne Folly.
Potoſi Mines ſeeme Midas's Hell; a Hold
For Dev'lls? what is digg'd-up is thought but Gold.
• n th' Andes-Hills, hee that Takes breath, does Looſe it;
Cold breath of Death! To view two Seas, who 'd Chooſe it?
The Plate-Streame ſeem'd at firſt a Silver-Mine:
But water there, not Silver, now does ſhine.
The Brazile-Cannibal is his Enimie's Grave!
Two Reſurrections yet at laſt they 'll have.
Wee ſought Guiana-Gold out at the Line:
Wee loſt a Raleigh, a farre richer Mine.
Cut Aegypt's Iſthmus South will ſome Seas goe?
Cut Darien-Iſthmus th' Ocean Weſt will flow.
The Old World ſtill did ſee New Generations.
Of Men: but Our World does behold New Nations.
New Spaine, France, England, now Riſe in the Weſt:
In our Sunne-Set they Riſe, if they prove Beſt.
Mexico firſt was founded in a Lake:
Was't not in Earth, Aire, Water, a Miſtake?
In Feather-worke the Mexican's ſo quaint;
That Feather is the Creature and the Paint.
A Spaniſh Card of the North-Seas was playd:
To Mocke, not Guide, ſome thinke it firſt was layd.
Diverſe a North-Weſt-Paſſage faine would find:
The Wind's content; The Frozen Sea's Unkind.
America's North's Triangle; South's a Heart:
Bee th' Iſthmus Faith, from God can th' Indian ſtart?

div.head: BOOK IV. OF Languages and Arts.

lg.l: WHat by an Angell's donne with Inſtant Thought,
That by Diſcourſe, in Man About is brought.
• ightly to Underſtand is Happineſſe:
• oore 't is, what's Underſtood, well to Expreſſe.
• rammar does Guide the Tongue; Logique the Reaſon:
• hey witt-up Youth to Man in Nature's Seaſon.
• het'rique does Language grace: in Age 't is Youth:
Tis not meere Shape; the Beauty 't is of Truth.
Sceleton to th' Eye preſents each Bone;
• ith Truth, not pleaſure: Bare 't is, and Alone.
• he Divine Wiſdome does Man's Frame preſent;
• ut cloths each part with Fleſh, its Ornament.
• he Mind formes Thoughts, Thoughts, Words: which undivided,
〈◊〉 Art's Choice Order, aptly may bee Guided.
• ature produces Art; by Helpe Divine
• he Curious Worme extends his Silken Line.
•• e Eare is a great Critique; and can tell
〈◊〉 ſound, if but an Accent falls not well.
〈◊〉 a Greeke ſlippe Caninius ſtraight would Smile:
• anklin would ſay, that it does All quite ſpoile.

Great Judges of Jöt •
count nor Litle,
The errour of a Breathing, or a Tittle.
Without your Art-Markes Language knows no Laws;
The Wrinkles of the Knuckes have their Cauſe.
Heralds of Accents Books and Braines'doe Vexe,
To Place the Grave, th' Acute, the Circumflexe.
Stephanus is Great Treaſurer o' th' Greeke:
To Joſeph ſo for Bread th' Aegyptians ſeeke.
Though Athens for Choiſe phraſe was a Choiſe peece,
Budaeus 't was, that was the Greece of Greece.
Slips th' Hebrew Accent, Schindler ſtraight deſcries it:
Maire too: but Curious Donat moſt defies it.
Weigangmeir Tables-up each point and Letter;
It can not ſtirre: You 'll find it in its ſetter.
Does Pagnine or Marinus Maſſe-up words?
Hutter's or Schwenter's ſmall Cube all affords.
Kirſten and Raphelenge are th' Arabique Moone:
Erpen, Giggeius, Pococke are High Noone.
Megeſer Turkiſh ſhow; The Perſian, Greave:
What Tongue untaught doe ſome or other Leave?
Great Mithridate ſpake Dialects Twenty-too:
With Halfe th' Art Nimrod had made more adoe.
Your Throtling Tongues who would not ſcape? They're worſe
Then Ignorance! To Learne then is the Curſe!
The Weſt-Tongues to the Latin, are but ſleight:
They are but oblique Caſes from the Right.
The Slipp'ry French, and Mouth-roof'd Spaniſh know
No Mean: Th' Italian does more wiſely flow.
Mechóac an Out-ſmooths Latin, as Fame ſays:
The Fiction ſure is ſmoother then the Phraſe.
Latin is Rhet'rique; Rhet'rique's Muſique too:
It does the Eare, by Art of Leaſure, woe.
All Art is Logique: in All 't is th' Immixt
Cement: Reaſon in Man is not more Fix'd.
Logique Defines, Divides, Collects; and Can
Clear Fallacy. It is the Man of Man.
Logique, they ſay, is glad to goe on foot:
It treads ſure ground then; els it could not doe't.
Peter of Spaine, a Logique-Pope, who 'll ſay,
Was Poore? Popes have Sixe thouſand pound a day.
Suicet's Old Subtil'ties did fall to Banding
With's Yong: His Witt grew paſt his underſtanding.
Witt by it ſelfe and Language is ſtill ſhow'n;
Yet without Pride: It can not els bee know'n.
Demosihenes did Reine th' Athenian's neck:
His Eloquence, though it could ſpurre, could Check!
In Tully ſee how high Rhet'rique can grow:
Hee was Rome's Tiber, when 't does Over-flow!
Rome's High Witt, Porcius Latro, no man Can
With higheſt Witt Out-ſpeake, or ſpeake the Man.
Quintilian's Bees ſuch Hony have brought home;
Who would not long to taſt ſo ſweet a Combe?
Tyre calls Choiſe Maximus Hers: Indeed, the Man
Is Milke and Hony; a meere Canaan.
Poetry is Witt 's Spring-Tide, On it rowles;
And what it meetes, Surmounts, or els Controules.
H • mer's th' Atlantique Ocean, wherein brave
Nature expatiates in Voluminous wave.
Ma • o, though ſome may ſeeme of higher ſtraine,
Thy blood flowes Rightly in thy Happy Veine.
• ucan, thy Age was leſſe, then thy Great Story:
But thy Great Witt has Doubled Age with Glory.
Statius his Witt and Language is ſo brave;
Hee's in his Witts, and yet may ſeeme to Rave.
Statius makes Capaneus ſo fierce a Wonder,
As if hee durſt ſtand to Conteſt with Thunder.
Martiall, th' art a ſure Mark's-man; what thy Dart
Of Witt Aimes at, it Hitts, and makes it Start.
• vid was baniſh'd Rome: 't had been more fit,
Wantonneſſe had been baniſhd from his Witt.
Claudian in too ſtraite Compaſſe does Ingage
His Muſe: Hee is a Lion in a Cage.
The Senecas in their Tragedies doe ſhow
That Witt, which they to Spaine, not Greece, did owe.
• eemes Lycophron to write, or rather Thinke?
• r writ hee with Caſſandra's Teares, white Inke?
•• aliger rendred Lycophron in jeſt:
• n Verrian Latin, like his Senſe, hee's Dreſs'd.
• ucretius, Nature's Favorite, excels;
〈◊〉 All's Truth; or, if not Too Much hee tells.
How vainly at th' Olympique Games, Renowne
Was ſought by Kings! Pindarus winnes the Crowne.
Though to the Grape Anacreon did incline,
His Song is Above Grape; His Witt's his Wine.
Horace, thy Art of Ode is choice: 't will Pleaſe
Whiles Mankind ſhall delight in Song and Eaſe.
Heav'n, Purgatory, Hell, were Dante's Three Themes.
Two were Wiſe Melancholy; yet Extremes.
What Petrach Loſt, hee kept: His Laura dies:
Hee Loſt his Love, not Wit: his Wit was Wiſe.
Bartas, the Sunne makes Halfe the World ſtill Bright:
Thou doſt Illuſtrate All both Day and Night.
Without Arithmetique wee can't know God:
Wee muſt diſtinguiſh between Ev'n and Odd.
Needs muſt wee know, what is One, Two and Three:
How know wee els, what is a Trinity?
To Add, Subtract, Multiply and Divide,
Does private Doubts, and publique too, Decide.
To Number Rudely, is to doe it Ill:
What muſt bee donne, who would not do •• c with Skill?
Wee may have Napier's Bones, or Pratt's ſmall Table:
Number and Art will thence us ſoone Inable.
A Seav'nth Day and Ten Laws Number require:
The Art then, as the Law, wee ſhould Deſire.
If Holy Meditations you'd Rehearſe,
How will you find the Chapter and the Verſe?
Can wee forget how holy David prays,
God would him reach th' Arithmetique of his Days?
Who takes the Book of Numbers in his hand,
Without Arithmetique can he Underſtand?
Muſique's Number in Sound: Inſtruments long
Since, Jubal made; and Moſes had his Song.
David kept Number in his Dance: yet free
His Voice and Joy were; as his Harpe would bee.
Saint Paul, who bids our Joy breake-forth and ſing,
Forbids not to the Voice to Adde the ſtring.
Boethius's Learned Muſique and his Witty
Philoſophy, are th' Happy Tune and Ditty.
Muſique ſo variouſly affects Men's Minds,
The Art is not more wondrous, then the kinds!
Th' Jonique's Quicke; Lydian, Sweete; Phrygian, Brave;
Aeölique's Soft; Mixt is All; Dorique's Grave!
If Lands were not Divided, Men would bee:
The uſe then of Geometry wee ſee.
When Joſhua into Canaan Iſrael brought,
Meaſure kept peace: els all had come to nought.
Between Some Tribes Jordan became a Line:
Diviſion 't was, which Tribe to Tribe did Joine.
In the Beginning had not Paradiſe bound?
It had layn open els, as common ground.
God meaſur'd Goſhen with a Line of Light;
When 't was Divided from th' Aegyptian's Night.
Meaſure can meaſure Light; Hence th' Optique Art;
Miſtaken view has made an Army Start!
The Waters have ſeem'd blood by dusky light:
The ſame ſeemes not the ſame by Different ſite.
To enlighten Light Vitellio does ſurpaſſe:
To ſee Reflected Light, Porta's a Glaſſe.
By light Collected, Archimedes fir'd
A fleete: Rare Art! But th' Artiſt's moſt admir'd.
To know Refraction, needs a helpe but ſmall:
The Aire and Water's Mathematical.
Meaſure and Number ſpread and Dreſſe the Sky:
Diſtance and Starres teach us Aſtronomy.
How the moiſt Pleiades, how Orion ſhines,
Aſtronomy, and Scripture too, Defines.
Without Aſtronomy Time knew no Dreſſe:
The Markes were loſt: Story were Wilderneſſe.
Scaliger would mend Time; Petavius would
Mend his Amendment: Art by Art is School'd!
From Cenſorinus Diff'rent Yeares wee know;
From Lalamantius, ſinces Doubts els might grow.
Some have thought Lilius's Account well donne:
Their Diall's ſham'd by Clear Vieta's Sunne.
From Earth and Heav'n Ptolomy wonne renowne:
Deſerv'd not this No-king a ſtarry Crowne?
Copernicus does erre with great pretence
Of Art: but Galilaus erres by ſenſe.
Who in his Eyes will place his Faith, may know,
The Dev'l a lie may by Permiſſion ſhow.
Great Tycho Brahe Inſtruments did fit
To Meaſure Heav'n; Siz'd by his worke, or Wit?
Waggoner does the world's Chiefe Havens ſound:
For Our Laſt Port, a ſurer Pilot's ſound!
To know the Loadſton's Myſteries and Law,
Gilbert's the Loadſtone, that does All men Draw!
Lomazzo's a rich peece, which it ſelfe praiſes:
Whiles Art by Light and ſhade, juſt wonder Raiſes!
Antiquities Refine Times from Fire and Flood:
By Statues Time's Recall'd and Underſtood.
Tais'ner ſhows Seventeen Hundred different Hands:
By's Owne, Hee's Gypſy: Them who underſtands?
Strabo, almoſt what Country, but th' haſt View'd it?
Had'ſt been a Judge, Mankind would ſu • e have rued it.
Euclide and Rathbourne may lay-out a Bound:
Vitruvian Art muſt Build upon the Ground.
Search wee the Mine for Gold, ſtraight make a Vau't
Wee muſt; els quickely all will bee at ſau'ce.
Come, Lets be Wiſe, and for the Arts Rejoice:
God's Word is Chiefe; yet Art too is God's Voice!

div.head: BOOK V. OF Philoſophers and Hiſtorians.

lg.l: High Metaphyſique, that on Horeb Dwelſt;
Great Queen of Reaſon; Thou All Arts Excell'ſt!
Religion, Thou on Sinai's Top doeſt ſit,
Higher then Horeb; Empreſſe of All Wit!
Horeb was but Aſcent to Sinai's Top:
Bleſſings from Sinai may on Horeb droppe.
Lets Teach what wee are Taught: not Inſpiration
Wee now doe bring; but Nature's Demonſtration.
Reaſon Alone in Man High Truths can reach:
Miſtaken Inſpiration can't ſo teach.
Before Time Somewhat Was, that could Make Time:
That Being therefore muſt bee Moſt Sublime.
That Being was but One: had it been Two,
What One did, then his Equall might Undoe.
The Firſt One muſt bee True; els 't is not One:
What's Feign'd No Being has; and ſo is None.
What's True is Therefore Good: and thus wee know,
All Goodneſſe els, muſt from This Goodneſſe flow.
The Firſt One, True, and good, by a clear Right
Of Pow'r, as Being, muſt bee Infinite.
How, what was Firſt, was Firſt, exceeds All wonder!
Whiſper has more proportion unto Thunder!
What knowledge may of the Firſt Being bee,
Nature firſt Learnes of what's Philoſophy.
What's Good, wee ſoone Corrupt: thus with the Love
Of Wiſdome, that's Philoſophy, it did prove.
Some thought all Knowledge could but Probable bee:
For them to Affrme' • , was 't not Abſurdity?
Some thought No Knowledge Man could have at all:
How knew they then, what they did Ignorance call?
The Doubtfull's Vex'd; the Ignorant is Mad!
Hee that Attaines Sure Truth, is Surely Glad.
An Ague ſome, Phyſitian's Bluſh doe name:
Are Hidden Qualities the Philoſopher's ſhame?

From Diff'rent phanſies Diff'rent Sect •
ariſe:
Thus Seeking Wiſdome ſome become unwiſe.
The Sceptiques in uncertainties ſtill dwelt;
The Stoiques Over-wiſe no paſſions felt.
Pythagoras by his Father, was a Jew;
Circumcis'd: known and Taught by Ezechiel too!
Pythagoras with the Gods did ſeigne to dwell;
Lay hid, Return'd: and what had paſſ'd could tell!
Foole Man, that's his Owne Mocke! Whom pride makes quick
To Hope, to get a God-head by a Tricke!
Pythagoras did eat nor Fleſh, nor Beanes:
More does Hee, that Himſelfe from Himſelfe weanes.
Pythagoras did love Muſique's ſweet Cloſe:
Silence on's Scholers hee might well impoſe.
Godhead and Witt Empedocles does lacke:
Aetna holds Him; His Braſſe-ſlipper's caſt backe!
From ſpeach with God Moſes his • ace did ſhine:
Plato having read Moſes, ſeem'd divine.
Plato's Ideas ſhap'd in Heav'n what's Heere:
Did hee then ſee his owne Idea There?
The Stagirite, that in all Arts excell'd,
• new not Himſelfe, nor how the Ocean Swell'd.
• pinion's made Mens God; their Joy then ſure:
• v'ry Philoſopher's Thus an Epicure.
When Ariſtotle did make Sleepe his Theme,
• hould hee have writt Waking or in a Dreame?
For Skill i' th' Creatures Aldrovand's ſo Fam'd,
You'd thinke 't were Adam, who the Creatures Nam'd.
Serpents, with Geſner, wee may ſafly view:
Learning hee had; yet hee no Jugling knew.
Salvian ſo preſents your various Fiſh,
Hee may bee the Carthuſian's wiſeſt Diſh.
Wiſe Dioſcorides, wheres' ere hee grew,
Was a rare Plant; Beſt Artiſts Him muſt view.
Aeſop ſaw Man oft become Beaſt: His wit
By Beaſt then, to ſhew Man, might thinke it fit.
Kind Heraclitus's Eyes with Teares ſtill ranne:
Democritus ſtill Laugh'd: Both make One Man.
Socrates's wiſdome did to Vertue tend:
Hee did Himſelfe, that would all others, mend.
Diogenes did Philoſophy O're-doe:
Hee made Vertue Abſurd, and ſo ſcarce True.
Cebes wiſely inſtracts us in his Table:
'Tis True Liſe; yet, like Life, lookes like a Fable.
A Good Example ſtill continues New:
Cleanthes's Tankerd is the Conduite too.
To Man's ſhort life an Memory Thou doeſt ſize
Thy worke, Good Epictetus: Brieſe and wiſe!
Seneca's a rare Surgeon; Hee Inures
His hand to Gentleneſſe; pleaſes and Cures.
Seneca's perſevering Wit was Good,
Till from his Open'd Veines flow'd Lines of Blood.
The Moraliſt with skill ſcarce more profound
Dreſſes the Mind, then Others dreſſe the Ground.
Contented Houſe-hold-Art cares not to Roame
Abroad; 't is its Owne Happy World at Home.
How prudent Heſiod Laws of plow rehearſes,
Breaking the Mould with a Glad Teeme of Verſes?

How Mar •
does the Bee home lo • den bring
With Hony? Hee's a Bee without a ſting.
How Varro does both Hen and Neſt prepare?
The Chick's Halfe-hatch'd, by his fine Wit and Care.
For Farmer's Life Quaint Tuſſer All containes:
The Wains, the Chains, the Swains, the Pains, the Gaines.
For Village-Lord, Brave Hereſha • h does marke
What's Worth: Hee's a N • ah in his Arke •
Th' Italian's La Leſina ſhows, what ought
In Curious Thrift bee ſav'd. Wee'll ſave a Thought.
Philoſophy is Humble, like the Eye:
On Earth it Dwells; and yet ſurveys the Sky.
See Story, Life's Example; how it ſpreads
A Patterne; in which out man All men reads.
Where Moſes his High Hiſtory began,
Who knows? Was Sinai's Top his Vatican?
Moſes is Text; Joſephus is Tradition:
Him our Faith reads; This read wee with ſuſpicion.
Herodotus is a World, part Truth, part Fable:
To know • are Truths yet, wee 're by Him more able.
Herodotus is Hiſtory's Freſh Youth:
Thucidides is Judgement, Age and Truth.
Herodotus is Gold of a Rich Veine:
Thucydides no Melting needs! Pure Graine!
Story ſuppoſes Rule; Then patterne Finds:
Xenophon yet to Rule hiS Cyrus Winds.
Philoſopher, Hiſtorian, Warriour too,
Who Xenophon inſtyles, ſpeakes but-his Due.
Who can not Oſt ſweete Xenophon repeat,
And ſee from Perſia his Admir'd Retreat?
Polybius againſt Hannibal Counſaile gave:
His pen preſents him yet profound and Brave.
Greece rais'd, Polybius, ſtatues to thy Glory:
But thy moſt laſting ſtatue's thy Owne Story.
The Heathen World's Antiquities may know,
They All to Sicilie's Diodorus Owe.
Thirty years toile it Diodorus coſt,
That, in the World, the World might not bee Loſt.
Brave Saluſt, thy rare Witt and Pen ſo act,
As if th' hadſt been with Catiline in his fact.
Choiſe Salust, Thou thy ſelfe can'ſt ſo Diſguiſe,
Th' art Ingurth, Fierce; and Manſiniſſa, Wiſe!
Caeſar's Memorials are Pure, Modeſt, Plane:
Had's Life been ſuch, h' had ne're at home been ſlaine.
Halicarnaſſius did Dionyſius breed:
Rome had of Him, then Hee of Rome, more need.
Rome's old Rites Dionyſius's Care has ſhow'n:
Rome now were els unto in ſelfe unknow'n.
Livie's Rome's Empire! Glorie's Ample Spheare!
Senators, Gen'rals, Provinces are There!
Valerius Maximus with ſuch light abounds,
Hee's a bright Set of pointed Diamonds!
Paterculus his Wit we muſt commend;
Unleſſe where hee appeares an Over-friend.
Had Curtius march'd with Alexander, Word
And Art had conquerd All without the Sword.
When whither'd Salem felt the wrath of God,
Joſephus was a bud on Aaron's rod.
Joſephus, but where from the Text hee ſtrays,
For JeW's Affaires allmoſt in all things Sways.
Story is Patterne: well Compar'd 'tis Double:
Ours is the Gaine, Plutarch: The Taſke's thy Trouble.
Pcace; you ſhall ſtraight heare a Court-Whiſper: Thus
To Liſten, may n't wee learn by Tacitus?
What Lucke thy Witt had, Tacitus, to marke
Rare Secrets? had'ſt thou Catt's eyes in the Darke?
A Secretary Sueton was, and knew
The Counſailes of th' Emp'rour, and th' Empreſſe too?
Sueton his Method does from Rhet'rique take:
Tacitus keepes the Order Time does make.
Sueton and Tacitus too much did know;
And, but that Shame's Heav'n's Vengeance, too much ſhow!
• a • ſanias, choiſeſt Travailour, Thy Fields
Are Greece: 'Tis Thine, what Rare it yields.
Justin, whither thou doſt contract or Make,
Wee 'll praiſe the for thy Owne and Trogus 's ſake.
Though thy Great work, Juſtin, about does rowle,
Yet thy Great Wit does thy great worke Controwle.
Florus is Livie's Margent; yet does Vie:
Liv • e's a Goodly ſtatue! Florus th' Eye.
Thought and Tongue by Herodian is refin'd:
Politian is his Mercury and Mind.
New Livie, Dion! Thou, whoſe Life was Story,
• halt by thy Pen Live with a Double Glory!
To Search Vopiſ • us and ſome few, who writ
Like Actions, Aeſop's cocke may reach us wit.
〈◊〉 wiſh Euſebius, when on thee I look▪
Thou hadſt been the Beſt Chriſtian in thy book.
Marcelline Senſe, ſcarce Words, could well Command:
Hee writte ſure with his Gauntlet on his hand.
Severus, Chriſtian Florus, Other Men
Whiles Thou ſo writ'ſt, thou merit'ſt Thy Owne Pen.
Story of late from Tacitus takes life;
Good ſtories of bad Actions now are rife.
Guicciardine Drifts and Shifts of Crimes has Writt:
Cambden and Strada ſhow Wiſdome and Witt.
Europe's Intelligencer Thua • us brings
To light, the more Retir'd Affaires of Kings.
In Priorato's ſtory Warriours march:
But due to Him is the Triumphal Arch.
Venetian Paul's Trent-Columne Fix'd does ſtand:
The neighbour Alpes are not a firmer Land!
The Centuries are Truth's • ulwarkes on a Rocke:
The Winds, the Seas may beat: They'll ſtand the Shocke.
Baronius His Roma's ſtory does Indite:
The Centuriſts doe the Church-ſtory write.
Baronius's Pyramids Renowne do winne:
Yet is there Embalm'd Rottenneſſe within!
HIppocrates and Galen are renown'd,
Though Health's a Riddle no where to be found.
An Atome's Reſtleſſe; witneſſe the Sunne's beam:
A Droppe's ſtill Chang'd; though ſtill 't is the ſame ſtreame!
For Health to the Phyſitian all Men goe:
Health yet, is 't the Phyſitian's Friend or Foe?
Hippocrates with Art the World did fill:
Yet his Pure Oath's more Wonderous, then the Skill.
Phyſitians are Halfe-Prieſts: if then Impure,
Or Blabs they bee; they rather Wound then Cure.
Phyſique's as Old as Sinne: Indure
Diſeaſe, ſince Nature can't, it ſtraight ſeekes Cure.
All Ages have their Helpe: Diet is Art:
Polybus, Nature's Scholar, taught this part.
Hyſsop is purging; purging makes Man New:
'T was well then Solomon the Herbal knew.
Diocles both Phyſitian was, and ſure
Phyſique! Fore ſhews Diſeaſe and preſent Cure!
Mithridate his owne Antidote became:
That was Right king-craft! who els claimes That Fame?
Choiſe Dioſcorides makes Man ſo wary,
Hee may become his own Apothecary.
Archigenes his Witt the Spunge does Squeeſe:
Thought hee upon his Patient and his Fees?
Apicius's Cookery was a fullſome • oile:
Wee ſcarce preſcribe Salt, more then Hee does Oile.
Celſus is Art and Elegance: it were
A Curious Art, to cure men by the Eare.
Brave Oribaſius did with skill abound?
For wounded Julian yet what skill was found?
To thinke the Bodie's Temperament does Guide
The Soule, Great Sinners are on Galen's ſide.
Galen is Man: his workes the Bodies Frame:
Their Number and perfection all praiſe claime.
Galen did live, as Some ſay, Seav'n ſcore years;
A rare Phyſitian ſure them; it appears.
Rhazes for learned practice is a new
And clear Hippocrates and Galen too.
At ten years old Avicen's Zeale and Art
Vied: H' had allmoſt All th' Alcoran then by Heart!
Avicen writes of Cordials; with the reſt
• et numbers not Himſelfe, though farre the Beſt.
Avicen's Canticles briefly renew
Memory: Canon th' are, and Cordials too.
To Make thy Canons, Avicen, which Containe
All Art of Health, thy Canon was thy Braine.
• uſhius ſoiles Avicen, Phyſitian's Mirroir;
• ee brake before Threeſcore: That was an Error.
Who th' Aphoriſmes wants, wants Art and Eaſe:
To want rare Faventinus is Diſeaſe.
Maſſaria, had thy Care and Judgement gone
Through All thy Art, wee had then All in One
• aſſavol's th' Apothecary's Commiſſion:
• aſſavol is the Rareſt Compoſition.

〈◊〉
Ancient times their Phyſique-Rules were True:
〈◊〉 Theſe, Truth's ſo Refin'd, that Truth ſeemes New.
• ugenius dares Maſſaria to refute:
Witt againſt Witt is ſtill in glad Diſpute.
Accurate Argenterius will not reſt
〈◊〉 Old Truths: Hee • ll conſult with his Owne breaſt.
Suchten your Antimony does cry-up;
By Art and Hope now Form'd into a Cup.
Anatomy and Surgery doe raiſe
Fallopius's Name: from Quicke and Dead h' has Praiſe.
The learned Wecker's books Secrets Unfold:
If ſo, Secrets they are but till they're told.
Experience has taught Cures: but who is 't knows
The true Diſeaſe? This Rondeletius ſhows.
Montanus, though't ſeemes Paradoxe, does hold
And prove, Diſtill'd, or Hot Waters, are All Cold.
A Golden Tooth grew in a Child Though All,
Ruland, admire; was Nature Chymical?
Mercurialis's Praiſe and Worth mount high;
Yet in his Ointment may bee found a Fly!
Kind Montagnana, though on Land, does ſhow,
How they are Orderd, that by Sea doe goe.
Bright Capivacci • s, praiſing Thee wee 've donne:
Is 't Art to hold a Candle to the Sunne?
Sweet Fracaſtorius, thou waſt double bleſt:
Thy Muſe, or Phyſique; who knows which is beſt?
Dutch Æſculapius, Paracelſus, Dar'ſt
By Art Frame Man; and with God's Worke Compar'ſt?
Would Nature ſeeme to make Old Galen New?
Of Great Forestus it may ſeeme but True.
Whiles with Courteous Fernelius wee but Talke,
• nto his Art hee does us Gently walke.
Quakes any at his Climacterical Year?
Codronchius will Rule him from his Fear.
From Phyſique did Wiërus runne to Evil?
Shall wee begin in Art, and End in Devil?
Curious Mizaldus, writt hee Wrong or Right,
Can not bee read, without a Choiſe Delight.
Sound Cordus, Thy Diſpenſatory teaches
Such Art, as ſcarce Another Artiſt reaches.
Man's Heav'n and Earth: from Heav'n and Earth's his Cure:
The Med'cine, Earth; the Time, Heav'n muſt Aſſure.
Maginus's Art and Confidence will tell,
How Phyſique with Aſtrology muſt dwell.
• age, in his Calculated Tables, ſhows
The Sicke Man's ſtate: His Death's Day too Hee knows!
A Queſtion't were decided not with eaſe,
If Cluſius were Phyſitian, or Diſeaſe!
Feaver, Stone, Dropſy, Coliques, Cluſius pain'd.
Some vaunt, they can all diff'rent Pulſes ſhow:
Can phanſy? Senſe this Riddle ne're ſhall know.
Seaſons of th' year, five thouſand times though paſs'd,
Only Catoſius does know now at laſt!
Sanctorius 's Phyſique is the Body and Scales:
Weigh Right, and mend: Thanke thy ſelfe, if Health failes.
Obicius would Sanctorius 's Worke Demoliſh:
Which coſt the Builder, Thirty years to poliſh.
Sanctorius, a Wiſe Builder, does with Care,
His Statique Art, which hee well Rais'd, Repaire.
All Helmond writes, wee'll hope to ſay, Is Good;
When wee ſhall underſtand, All's underſtood.
Some ſecrets Helmond ſhows, which were more fit,
If True, to bee conceald! Hence, Dangerous Wit!
Sennertus does all arguments purſue
So well, Hee's Text and Commentary too.
Venice, thy Trincavel yields thee a Name
Beyond thy wedding Ring, though of great Fame.
When Galen and Hippocrates ſeeme foes,
Learned Rorarius does the ſtrife Compoſe.
Whiles great Hippocrates obtaines his Due,
Hollerius ſhall bee Aphoriſme too.
Crato, thy wiſe and plentiful Adviſe,
Shows, thou gott'ſt ſame not from ſome New Diviſe.
Cauſes of ſodaine Death Terillus tells:
Wiſdome, and prayer, ſometimes Death Repells.
The Quinteſſence of Man's Blood is rare Cure:
The Quinteſſence of God and Man's moſt Sure!
A Child Cried in the wombe, Libavius ſays;
Did hee begin his Griefes, before his Days?
Horſtius the Lover's pulſe by Art would find:
Lets learne by Grace the pulſe of our Owne Mind.
Baldus man's mind will tell vi • wing his Nalles:
Place the Commandements there, the Art ne're failes.
From Curtius th' Art of Doſing let us learne:
Strong Phyſique does not a weake mind concerne.
Crinitus, Weigh'ſt Man's Heart? If Grace it fill,
'Tis Light: If Empty 't is, then ſinke it will.
Melampus by the Bodie's Moles would ſaigne
Divine: by Inward Spots it were not Vaine.
Anatomiſts Man's Body ſtill ſo View,
As if this Art, when Man Dies, ſtill were New!
Laurentius is th' Anatomiſt of his Art,
Tranſcending in the Philoſophical part.
New Remelinus takes off Man's firſt Skinne:
So by Degrees unclothes each part within.
Platerus Chippes-out Man, and ev'ry part
Lays by it ſelfe, with ſpeciall Care and Art.
Veſalius does Fallopius diſſect:
Anatomy by Anatomy is Check'd!
Bartholine's Art and Eye are Quicke of ſight:
His View's Review: hee does the Mind Invite.
Caſserius the Inſtruments of Senſe does ſhow:
Our Senſes to His Reaſon This doe Owe.
Spigelius preſents Man, as at his Riſe:
You'd thinke yee ſaw Adam in Paradiſe.
Some the Anatomy of the Living write:
Let th' Eye to its Owne Conſcience caſt its ſight.
Has ev'ry ſore a Salve? Eraſtus then,
Not Paracelſus, proves the Man of Men!
Libavius the Pariſian Checke does ſleight:
Shewing what Chymiſtry hee does count Right.
Libavius does your Crollian Magique try:
And to the Roſeal Croſse has a like eye.
What's ſearching Lullus, the Philoſopher's Stone
And Augurellus? Sure their Worth's All One!
Camphire-Oile, and ſome more, for Liquid Gold,
With Gold-Duſt, paſſe; by Beguin yet contro • ld.
What's not perform'd by Nature, Art or Grace,
Is Bad: where then ſhall Weapon-Salve find place?
Taliacotius will a main'd face Cloſe
To anothers fleſh, and thence make a new noſe!
Mathiolus and Lobel are choiſe plants:
Without Them th' Herbal would confeſſe its wants.
If to the Spaw a journy thou wouldſt make,
G • ringus and Byetius with thee take.
Who Travaile would by Sea, Waggon, Horſe, Foote;
By Gratarol's Advice may better doc't.
The Inſtruments of ſpeech in Beaſts, who reach?
Rare Aqua-Pendens yet ev'n This dares Teach.
Quercetan does a learned Choiſe propoſe
Of Meats: Hee does deſerve the Helpe hee ſhows.
Old Trapezuntius did his Skill and Name
Forget by Sickneſſe: Sickneſſe was His Fame.
Drinke, fourteen Ounces daily, by juſt w • ight,
Bread and Meat Twelve! Cornar • 's ſtrict Receite!
Who was the Beſt Phyſitian? ſhall wee ſay?
Judge by ſucceſſe; It was Methuſ • elah.
Allmoſt a Thouſand years Methuſhelah told:
In God's Account hee was not One day Old.
Twice as much Bread as Fleſh; Thriſe as much eat,
As Fiſh: Once and a Halfe as Egge's Receite.
The Lampe is Life: Man's Heat does daily dry
His moiſture up; ſo that to Live's to Die.
What's Life, Health, Phyſique? though one daily quaff'd
With Thirſt and Phanſy, Doctor Antonie's Draught!
LEts keep Poſſeſſion; Cries the Law • er ſtill?
'T is well, if the Poſſeſſion proves not Ill.
Two things there are, the One of which is Mine:
The Other e're I have 't, ſhall I call Thine!
Nature, art Cain? ſayſt thou at ev'ry ſtrife,
Though Brother th' art, J'le have thy Goods or Li • e?
Nature, although Corrupt, will have ſome Law;
To ſcape wrong, wee'll doe Right: Danger does Awe.
Conſcience is Law, Accuſer, Witneſſe True;
Judge, Pris'ner, Jailour, Executioner too.
The Heav'nly Angels know their Laws: without
Order, Heav'n not Aſſembly were, but Rout.
The Dev'lls, that raiſe all ſtrife, ſtrife yet doe quell
Amongſt themſelves: A Law there is in Hell!
Relations muſt bee Own'd: Huſband and Wife;
Father, Sonne; Maſter, Servant: Order's Life.
The Head and Feet doe ſtill their Diſtance keep:
The Natural Bodie's Politique, ev'n in Sleepe.
No Nation but does in it ſelfe keep Law:
The Cannibal's Owne Family ſcapes his Maw.
Nimrod more ſought for Glory, then for Blood:
Much loſſe of This, Only with Juſtice, ſtood.
What Blood the Body looſes, the Head feeles:
There's quick Intelligence between Head and Heeles,
All Fault was Death with Draco: This Severe
Decree was Life: Safety thus ſprung from Feare,
Fraile are Man's Laws; Iſrael's Laws are ſure:
And only by Gods will Change or Indure.
Of Heathen Laws the Roman bears the Name:
In Diffrent Times yet, Roman's not the ſame.
Laws under Kings Rome had: P • pirius's Name
They beare, by Him Collected: Hee the Fame.
When Tribunes Rul'd, the Law uncertaine grew:
And Rome then thought, that All's not Beſt, that's New.
Troubles teach Witt: thus Rome did fetch from Greece
Laws in Ten Tables: 't was a Golden Fleece.
Ten Tables were at Rome to Twelve improv'd:
To helpe what wanted, Rome it ſo behov'd.
Th' Epheſian Hermodorus, though Exil'd,
The Authour is of Rome's Twelve Tables ſtyl'd.
Plato muſt write of Law; it was Intended
By Art and Blood: from Solon he deſcended.
Charondas 'gainſt his own Law, to his paine,
Comes arm'd to Councell: by's Own ſword hee's ſ • aine.
What Various Laws Rome's Common-Wealth did know,
Wee may: Zaſius ſhows Them: They him doe ſhow.
Papirian, Flavian, Aelian Law Rome knew:
Yet wiſe Neceſſitie ſtill added New.
Rome's People from the Senator's did fall:

Made Laws; and theſe The People's Law •
did call.
A People Needs a Senate: This does make
Laws, which their Name doe, from the Senate, take.

Rome's Prat ••
had his Honorarious Law:
At laſt the Conſul's Laws kept Alkin Awe.
The Senate gave Naſica Houſe and Fame:
For Law-Adviſe to Him the People came.
Servius a famous Orator, by ſhame
Wiſely provok'd, in Law got Skill and Fame.
Labeo in Rome ſix Months ſpents ſix he Writ
Retir'd: The Country was his Fame and Wit.
Ofilius's Learning; was their Difference.
Augustus did Himſelfe, whiles Law, advance:
His Noble Art ſham'd Wrong and Ignorance.
Man Rais'd Art; Art Man: Law did Lawiers reare:
Some knights, ſome Senators, ſome Conſuls were.
By Caracalla's Sword Papinian died:
Hee ſcorn'd to Excuſe an Emp'rour Fratricide.
Th' Imperial Laws, that lay before Disjoind,
By wiſe Juſtinian in One Code wee find.
What the Gregorian, Hermogenian Code,
And Theodoſian had, Tribonian ſhow'd.
Prophane and Greedy though Tribonian were,
Juſt and Free Art does his Name highly reare.
Law includes Pow'r and Wiſdom: Theſe wee find,
To have their Empire in Juſtinian's Mind.
The well Digeſted Pande • ts doe diſplay
The Law: whiles what the wiſeſt Lawiers ſay.
The Code has Pow'r: The Pandects have profound
Reaſon; Theſe are the Law's ſure Depth and Ground.
Law's Inſtitutions are the Youth of Law:
Law's Conſtitutions doe keepe Age in Awe.
The Novel Conſtitutions ſhow they are
As a new Code, ſorm'd with Authentique Care.
The Feudal Cuſtomes may as Pandects bee:
Their Right the Learned Lawiers make us ſee.
Wit teaches Wit: Th' Imperial Artiſts ſhow
Rome's Clergy, Wits which way they have to goe.
Scholars Quicke Scholars are: Gregory the Great
Sent-out commands, as Lofty as his Seat.
A Canon-Law Gratian's Decree does reare.
As the Church-Pandects, for a Thouſand year.
Gregory the Ninth unto the Church firſt ſhow'd
Decretal Conſtitutions Rome's Church-Code.
Th' Eight Boniface his Decretals does ſpread;
By Dynus's Art; which Roman Lawiers read.
Clemens the Fiſt His Decretals preſents:
Ambitious Men ſucceed to proud Intents.
The Two-and-Twentith John does make new roome:
Thus his Extravagant Conſtitutions come.
Rome's Church is now growne Empire: Has This Code?
Like Reverence to the Decretals is ſhew'd▪
Law Civil, has it Pandects? The Decree
Shall to the Roman Church as Pandects bee.
The Canoniſts, that doe their Taske purſue,
Have now, by Lancelet, Institutions too.
Has not the Church a ſurer Guide then Man?
With Scripture-Canon ſure the Church began.
Scripture's Church-Code: The firſt fow'r Councils know
They're Pandects, which Themſelves to This Code owe.
Th' Apoſtles Canons Zonaras explaines:
To Prove them, then to Expound them, is more paines.
The Gen'ral Church a Code had; th' African too 〈◊〉
All that is Good in Gratian is not New.
Iſidore, Burchard, Ivo, Laws Collected,
Which before Gratian, Church-Affaires directed.
Photius his Nomocanon's a Greeke Light:
Balſamon ſtrives to make it ſhine more bright.
Lotharius and Bononia Irnerius Cheriſhd:
By 's Interlinear Law-Gloſſe They too flouriſh'd.
Though Azo's Induſtry was more then's part;
His Summe's the Summe of Azo and his Art.
But for Accurſius Law had had a Loſſe:
Hee firſt, the whole Imperial Law did Gloſſe.
Who th' Emp'rour's Right Oppos'd Vinea defied;
Was hee not Wiſe? The Sword was on his ſide.
Accurate Hoſtienſis much does write:
His Learned Summe't is that does Much Invite.
Law's Looking-Glaſſe the clear Durantes writ:
A Glaſſe, in which you may behold his Wit.
Guido the Groſſe Clemens the Firſt became:
• oth Laws he knew; One Law hee Now might Frame.
Bartolus Law, it ſelfe is enough Fear:
Would'ſt thou both Pleader bee, and Judge Severe?
Baldus with ſtudy, Age and Fame ev'n weari'd,
• hy in Saint Francis Habit would'ſt bee buri'd?
• f Francis was, as Truth can Franc'is paint,
Baldus more Lawier was, then Francis Saint.
Panormitan in Baſil Counſil ſate
When Pope Eugenius had his Fate-well Date.
Jaſon did the Whole Civil Law expound:
Liv'd Long, and allmoſt fifty years Renown'd.
Zaſius in Law did Reaſon moſt eſteeme:
Of His Choiſe Thoughts hee ſhows us how to deeme.
For Practice in the Law Oldendorpe's Way,
As Once With Him, with Others ſtill may Sway.
Civil and Canon Law Oldendorpe's Care
Does Sort: Knows the Compariſon Compare?
Budaeus's Choiſe and Learning give ſuch Light,
Hee does New Pandects on the Pandects Write.
Alciat's Wit and Fame were Milan's Jewel:
His Owne was his ſelected worke, His Duel.
Cujacius, ſtill bee't Doubt, that neither boaſt,
If Thou to Law, or Law to Thee, Owes moſt.
Rare Weſembecius's Artificial Frame
Of Law, which Tully wiſh'd, Raiſes his Name.
The Inſtitutions many a Wit have Vext:
Mynſinger may bee Law without a Text.
Hotoman's worth is by his writing's knowne:
Could His Pen Junius Brutus's writings Owne?
Spaine on the Law Imperial will attend:

Her Covarruvia •
was her Pride and Friend.
Antonius Auguſtinus tries the Ground
Of Law; Hee the Twelve Tables does expound.
Calvin's an Honeſt Lexicon: who feares
To bee phraſe-jugled? Ev'ry word Hee Cleares.
The Greek and Roman Laws receive great praiſe
From Leunclavius: Sh • 'n't They His fame raiſe?
Exquiſite Gothofrede does ſo Tranſcend.
The Law's perfection makes us fear's will End.
The brave Welſh Solon, Howell D • a, much Glory
Unjuſtly wants: His worth does Claime more Story.
By Law of Wales no Morgaging of Land
Was good, unleſſe into a Kinſman's hand.
The Spring and Harveſt Welſh Vacations were:
No Suite For Land the Judges Then might heare.
Wales, at thy Judge's Right hand the Prieſt ſate;
Who with the Judges did Deliberate.
The Rhodian Laws ſhow Wellwood's ſettled Wit:
Though of the Sea, upon the Land he writ.
The Grecian Armes and Tongue prov'd both but vaine:
The Amphyctyones were the Wiſe Braine.
Linwood and Spelman Ancient wiſdome ſhow:
Noveltie's Danger: with Time Errours grow.
Cowell, Thou haſt Order'd the Law: giv'n Light:
Sunder'd what lay confus'd, and placed all right.
Littleton's Tenure's Ground: Free Land's rich mould:
Fee-Taile is Gravel: Sand is Copy-hold.
Lambard, Law's Antiquary, makes us ſee,
By what High Courts Once were, what they ſhould bee.
Fulbecke Law Civil, Canon, Common, ſhows:
Compares: Diſcovers, where they're Friends, where Foes.
Fitſherbert, what in Year-bookes lay confus'd,
Has wiſely ſav'd, from being more abus'd.
What is Engliſh Law's Hope after Clear Brooke,
Deep Plowden, Quick-brain'd Dyer, Learned Cooke?
Beware the Sharke: if in Law's Sea wee fall,
A limbe is loſt! If Loſt wee are not All.
Againſt Both Parts Law ſo does Oft prevaile,
They're Swallow'd worſe, then Jonah by the Whale!

div.head: BOOK VIII. OF Kings and Other Worthies.

lg.l: Juſt Empiere's Shuneſhine; Pow'r, that's got by wrong,
Is Tempeſt: A fierce Tempeſt laſts nor Long.
Nimrod was not of his owne Kin the Firſt:
The Chief he was: but what was worſe, the Worſt.
Semiramis, did'ſt ill, to rule thy Sonne?
Rule him whiles Child: when Man, His rule beguane.
Pharaoh's hard heart no ſhowres of grace obtaines:
Now wee'll beleeve in Aegypt it ſcarce raines.
Why did the Pharaohs raiſe ſuch maſſy Tombes?
Fear'd they to come unto their Heavier Doomes?
Tremble fond Pyramids! The Laſt Thunder can
Startle your Guilty Mumy into Man?
Vaine Pharaohs, when your Piles are hurl'd aſunder;
Not They, your Folly 't is, ſhall prove the Wonder.
Though Nimrod's Tow'r and Pride th' Aegyptians led,
Hee for the Living built; They for the Dead.
Moſes, to Die in Nebo, did God ſend?
Death was his Way: but Life't was, was his End.
Joſhua, Thou waſt King' of th' Holy ſword:
Was't double edg'd, like God's Victorious word?

Adonib • zec
• ut-off Thumbes and Toes:
Cruelty's Folly! Fear'd hee Kicks and Blows?
Envio • s and Bloody Saul! Nothing could winne him.
From his Fierce will: His worſt Wireh was within him.
David was Moone; knew Increaſe, Full and Waine;
Change too yet did in th' Heav'n of Grace remaine.
Solomon's Fame did from his Wiſdome riſe:
His Wiſdome, nay His Folly, makes Us wiſe.
David cut-off Saul's Skirt: The Ten Tribes doe
Leave Rehoboam but a ſkirt or Two.
Jehoſaphat made Judges: ſome agree,
The laſt great 'ſize ſhall in his Vally bee.
Sardanapalus did himſelfe perplexe:
This Diſtaffe-King could not himſelfe Unſex • .
Comes downe in Angel, and Deſtroys his Foes.
Impious Sennacherib blaſphem'd his Maker:
In his ſhed blood his Sonne with's Sonne's partaker.
Manaſſes loſt a Crowne; The Lot of Many •
Againe receives it; ſcarce the Lot of any!
Joſiah was Extremes; All Acclamation,
His Paſſover! His Death, All Lamentation!
High Nebucha Inezzar a God began
To Act: God made him Beaſt, to make him Man.
Wine in God's bowles Belſhazzar quaff'd in Flout:
That night by th' Enimie's Sword His Blood flow'd-out.
After Long Glory and its ſtrong deluſion,
Th' Aſſyrian Felt and Saw his Owne Confuſion.
The Mede th' Aſſyrians Spoild; Perſians the Mede:
Captiv'd in Sinne, Sinners thus ſinners lead.
Cyrus decreed God's Temple's Reparation:
Happy it was, if 't was his Owne Foundation.
A King and No King? Riddle, ſhall wee ſay?

By Eſther's hand thus Mordecha •
did ſway
Happy Aſſuerus whiles with Esther join'd:
Was't Jew and Gentile in one Chriſt refin'd?
Was Perſia's Glory in Darius Ended?
By his rare Patience was it not Extended?
Darius's Mother, Daughter, Wife (Love-ſnares)
Were Alexander's Captives; Not Hee Theirs?
Swift Alexander's Land-flood! Such his Sway
That his owne Fierceneſſe ſwept him ſoone away.
Was Alexander more then To • le and Sinne?
Vexing Deſires, in Greatneſſe, ſtill Beginne.
Great Alexander Living is the Great:
His Death, of Him and His was the Defeate.
Abuſive pow'r Callisthenes Defac'd:
Proud Alexander Himſelfe moſt diſgrac'd.
The Macedonian built his Horſe a Tombe:
A poiſon'd Hooſe provided Him Like roome.
The Macedonian Loſt the Aſian Throne:
His Kin ſoone Loſt, or never Got, their Owne.
Who gripes too much caſts all upon the ground:
Too great a Greatneſſe Greatneſſe does confound.
In Alexander's Wife 's and 's Children's blood
Caſsander's ſlipp'ry Throne no long time ſtood.
In th' Eaſt the Grecian's Pride firſt Rais'd its Creſt:
Perſeus captiv'd by Rome droop'd in the Weſt.
Scripture is Library: Aegypt, thy King
Ptolemy Philadelph Thee Both did bring.
Seem'd Pompey Rome's Head? Aegypt was Rome's ſtore;
When Pompey left his Coarſe on Aegypt's ſhoare.
Antony was devour'd by Aegypt's guile:
Faire Cleopatra was the Crocodile!
Anthiochus the Great, Fortune's ſhrine ſaigne
Would ſpoile: By Fortune was't? There hee was ſlaine!
Antiochus the Mad, God's Temple ſpoild:
Was plag • 'd; Griev'd; Died: 't was Gaine to bee thus ſoild.
The Macchabies, Apocryhal in Story,
The World ſtrives yet to Canonize in Glory.
Mithridate forty years a warre maintaind
With Rome: Hee Fought; hee Liv'd not; much leſſe Raign'd▪
Mithridate ſlew Wife, Mother, Child; Remorſe
Knew not! Some Wives, Hee Nature did Devores!
Rome was Tigranes his laſt Overthrow:
Active Tigranes was his Owne Firſt Foe.
Herod, though Foxe, more Crafty was, then Wiſe:
Hee's Foole, that acts crimes before Publique eyes.
Caeſar was Warre: Auguſtus Peace: Impure
Tiberius was; Caligula paſt Cure.
Claudius was Dotard; Nero beaſtly Mad:
Galba ſtale; Otho Trimme; Vitellius, Swad.
Vespaſian's Shrewd, and Baſe: Titus more Good
Then Bad: Domitian is Pride, Luſt and Blood!
Nerva's a Snuffe, that in the Socket blazes:
And ſoone gooes-out, whiles the Eye upon it gazes.
From Spaine to th' Indies Trajan did prevaile:
Of Chriſt and th' Indies Trajan yet did faile.
Adrian was Mercury; a Mixture ſtrange
Of Vice and Vertue; Of Great Art and Change!
Once Alexander could Diogenes bee:
Antonine, King and Stoique was in Thee.
Severus might amongſt the Beſt ſhine bright.
But that hee was th' Eclipſe of his Owne Light.
Who does not Commodus and Baſſian Loath?
Heliogabalus was Himſelfe and Both!
The Perſian ſtate Alexander O'rethrew:
Rome's Alexander did Himſelfe ſubdue.
Valerian Chriſtians vex'd: Sapores flayd him!
How Cruelty helpes Juſtice? They Repaid him!
Aurelian from Zenobia wonne ſome fame:
Zenobia's Worth did the fierce Conquerer came.
Great Conſtantine thou waſt the Spirits of Wine:
Thou gav'ſt the World Tincture, or Taſt, Divine.
Julian revolts from Chriſt: yet can not ſtart
From Death: was not Apoſtaſy the Dart?
Though Theodoſius Raged, his Happy Shame
Prov'd, Holy Ambroſe, His and Thy true Fame.
Attila's Pride and Futy did decline
At once: Hee Liv'd in Blood, and Died in Wine!
Depos'd Glycerius is, by Nepos's Will,
Made Prelate; Had hee ſeeming Empire ſtill?
A • guſtulus his Name was like his Throne:
A little Caeſar Firſt; then Quickly None.
• uſtinian gave Conſtantinople Law:
But Beliſarius's Sword the World did Awe.
• uſtinian, Beliſarius haſt Conremn'd?
Hee was thy priſ'ner: Thou 't is art Condemn'd.
Many Warres caus'd Ravenna's Exarchate:
Too many made Two hundred years its Date.
Mauritius Captive blood would not redeeme;
That ſhed; his owne did find as much eſteeme.
Charles the Great his battles did record
In blood: Hee writ them with the Spirit of Sword!
The Grecian Empire Conſtantine begunne:
And in a Conſtantine ſhall 't bee undonne?
Otho the Great did ſtoutly quell his foes:
This Double Caeſar did a Pope depoſe!
Hildebrand did Henry the Fourth debaſe:
But ſweet Revenge Raptur'd him from diſgrace!
Saladine to his grave bid his friends bear
His ſpoiles of th' Eaſt, his Shirt upon a ſpeare!
For Seav'nty years Rome to Avignon fled:
There Rome was, where Clemens the Fiſt, its Head.
Queen Joane of Naples ſo did act her Life,
Shee ſeem'd as much an Hoſteſſe, as a Wife.
England's Fiſt Henry was a Sunne too ſoone
Remov'd: Heav'n's Sunne's leſſe ſtrange: Ours ſet at Noone
Ziſca Alive his foes by Fight O'recome:
When Dead, hee'd Conquer with his Skin made Drumme.
Five hundred thouſand warriours fight with rage▪
Yet Bajazet can't ſcape Tamerlan's Cage!
Columbus was by his brave Spirit ſo hurl'd,
Hee ſeem'd the Sea-Apoſtle of the World.
Ferdinand from the Moores wonne his Owne Spaine;
From th' Indians, Gold: from Him They Heav'n ſhould gaine.
Charles the Fiſt ſcorn'd Glory, Pleaſure, Pelſe:
Turn'd Court-Monke and the Emp'rour of Himſelfe.
Henry of Portugal's Old Age was Spring:
Hee Liv'd a Cardinal, and Died a King!
Henry, Our Eight, few Painters have well made:
Some give him too much Light, ſome too much ſhade▪
Our Engliſh Mary in wrong Zeale's Deſire,
Poore Chriſtians Burnd: The Counſaile was the Fire▪
Elizabeth was Temper'd to Inherit
Her Grandſire's Wiſdome, and her Father's Spirit.
Scotland's Faire Mary Vext in Life and Story,
England has yet unridled to her Glory.
Drake in New Albion might a Crowne have worne;
Wiſely Denied: Though't was not made of Thorne!
When Truth, Peace, Juſtice, Mercy, Arts, did flouriſh,
Not Henry, but James Beau-Clerke did them nouriſh.
Charles the Firſt, the Firſt his people's Martyr!
A Saint was Too, by right of th' Holy Charter!
The Body ſtrikes-off its Owne Head! Strange deed!
The Head Cut-off, the Body Too Muſt bleed.
King of Rare Lott and Vertue, Charl's the Firſt!
The Beſt of Men! Judg'd, by the Worſt, the Worſt!
Beheaded England, ſtrange ſhall bee Thy Story:
Revive in thy New Charl's, to a New Glory!
Our High-Noone Starre, Charles the Second, Shines!
