'T is bleſt Succeſſe, when Heaven with Earth Combines!
With Glitt'ring Swords, yet without ſhedding blood,
See, Our Great Britan Comes! 'Tis Charles, the Good.
Yorke wing'd with Lightning, in a full carriere
Flies-on, and reſpites not his Foe to Fear!
Kind Glo'ſter ſeing Charles Bleſt 'midſt juſt Deſires;
To Heav'n, whence his Owne Graces came, Reti'res,
Kings Chooſe their friends: But Charles is ſuch Delight.
Hee is the Heav'n's and England's Favorite!
PAint mee a Polititian with right foote
Tip-toed, and Slily aiming for a ſhoote.
Your Politique, that will bee held moſt quaint,
Muſt ſeeme, nay bee Beleev'd to bee a Saint.
Nimrod had Art, before he had great Pow'r:
Hee built Himſelfe, before hee built his Tow't.
Semiramis her Sexe and Plot did Hide:
Scarce could ſhee els th' Aſſyrian Empire guide.
Nature taught Jacob Policy: by which
Hee made his Flock, and Him his Flock made Rich.
Shechem had Craft; but that on Luſt Heav'n Low'rs:
Let's Marry; then all Jacob's Wealth is Ours.
• f any a Shee-Politique would paint,
• otiphar's Wiſe is Copy for ſuch Saint.
The Midwives obtaine mercy, whiles they Muſe,
Their Mercy to the Hebrew Babes t' Excuſe.
Rahab on the houſe-top hid Iſraels ſpies:
Heav'n ſaw't; though 't had not been ſo neere the Skies.
• ael's ſharpe Naile through Siſera's Temples went:

• t was the ſureſt naile in Ja • l •
ten • .
Abimelech his ſeav'nty brethren kill'd:
By ſoulneſſe of his plot, his Plot hee ſpill'd.
Abſalon's Rage was more; Sampſon's more fit:
Both did fire Corne: but Sampſon with Foxe-wit.
Philiſtines th' Iſraelite no Smith afford:
Heav'n's plot! The Fooles doe fall by their Own ſword!
Michal helpes David's flight, faigning him ſaint:
Choiſe Wit! That makes an Image ſave a Saint!
Seemes David Mad? Feare 's Madneſſe: the Abuſe
Of Sanctity and Reaſon needs Excuſe.
David's friends ſcape in a well O'reſpread with Meale:
Them, not the Woman's Wit, it did conceale.
Achitophel did hang himſelfe; Wee 'll tell
But Truth too; Huſhai hang'd Achitophel.
Had faire Bathſheba ne're been Too much ſeen,
Faire though ſhee were, ſhee ne're had been a Queen.
Bathſheba's ſhape was her Firſt Wit: That Wit
Court-taught, in David's Throne made Solomon ſit.
A Crown to Jeroboam's a ſtrange thing;
That would adore a Calſe to bee a King.
Proud Athalia a King's Wife had been:
Rule ſhee will ſtill: Shee 'll Live or Die a Queen.
By Night the Mede did Baltaſar beſet:
By Night hee ſees, that can a Kingdome get.
Romulus gives Rome Bulke; Numa a Mind:
Yet, though his Wit ſees, his Devotion's Blind.
Hannibal to his Gods Rome's Empire vows:
Revenge for Sacrifice Heav'n n'ere allows.
Hannibal's Vow would have fierce Vengeance throwne
Upon Rome's head: it Falls upon his Owne.
Old Maſiniſsa's Wiſdome's his beſt Pow'r:
• ee leagues with Rome; Rome els would all devoure.
• ugurth's Truſt in a Father-in-law O're-ſways him:
• y Treachery, not Wit, Bocchus betrays him.
• ubtle, Stout, treacherous Jugurth, who can purge?
Who can ſcape God? The Roman was his ſcourdge.
• ertorius's Sword and Wit durſt try to doe
• s much as Romulus and Numa too.
• ome greedy Swine will kill their Yong: Is 't true?
• erod his Children kill'd: was This Hog Jew?
Sejanus, thy Tiberius was as Quick,
As Old: at laſt hee Show'd his Maſter-Tricke.
In Senate, Hopes Sejanus muſt adorne:
Strange! Hee's Accus'd; Mas'd; Hal'd; in peeces torn!
The Jews kill Chriſt, to ſave their ſtate: profound
Wit! But Humane! 'T was That did All confound!
At Once Rome Thirty Tyrants had: This Fits
A Monſter: Many Heads! How many Wits?
Shrewd Diocleſian Empire Got: Deſign'd
Partners! raign'd Long: then Rule and Wit Reſign'd.
Ruffinus Guards Arcadius; ſtill to raigne,
Raiſes the Gothes to warre; His Plot's his Bane.
Falſe Stilico brings down the Goth to Rome:
His Hope's his Throne: His Lot's worſe then a Tombe!
Eudoxia her Ambition ſhould exile,
Not Chryſoſtome, for all his holy toile.
Phocas deſtroys Mauritius; who does ſtraine
Conſcience for Glory, does miſtake his gaine!
Phocas by bold Heraclius 's ſword does fall:
Great Craft and Pow'r are Much; yet are not All!
France, whiles thy Kings grow ſlugges, Pipin intrudes:
Keepes Court: the King was but the Moveable Goods!
The Second Sylveſter, as fame then ranne,
Seem'd Witch: Indeed a Pope's a cunning Man.
Gregory the Seav'nth many a Pope had made:
At laſt hee became free of the ſame trade.
Alexander the Third by th' Painter's worke
Rodolfe betrayd to the Turke! The Pope 's more Turke!
Pope Alexander's Pride on th' Emp'rour trod!
Hee caſts contempt on Kings! A Vicar-God?
A foote-ſtoole-King may make Meere man ſo ſtout,
The Swelling Pride may give a Pope the Gout!
Th' Eight Boniface was great, till hee ſeem'd great:
H' had Wit to get, but not to keep, his Seat.
Laurence de Medices, Judge of Strife unjuſt,
Did in Himſelfe make friends Wiſdome and Luſt!
Caſtruccius toild with Conqueſt to bee great,
Looſes his Life and Plots with Cold and Heat!
Sforza a Duke and Traitour calls to his plot
Helpe: His Helpe 's Ruine! Jaile and Shame 's his Lot!
Pope Borgias did a poiſned draught deſigne:
Err'd hee in Faith? Erre hee did in the Wine.
Had Borgias Peter's Key? Miſchief of Sinne!
What is 't to Open Heav'n, and not Get-in?
Borgias his Sonne Caeſar was ſold to Evil:
Proceeding hee took all Degrees of Devil?
Whiles Others Death Proud Caeſar Borgias ſought
His Pois'nous Plot upon his Owne plot wrought.
Miſtaken Borgias by High projects led,
Like Sampſon, pull'd the houſe upon his head.
Macchiavell's working Mind ſtories compacts
Into new Rules: Bold Judge of ſacred Acts!
Were Macchiavell's Prince, Satyre, paſſe it might
As Florence-Libel; Witty, if not Right.
Macchiavell's Wit nothing but Danger winnes,
If't Undertakes the ſhame of Others Sinnes.
In ſadneſſe Macchiavel thou didſt not well
To helpe the World to runne faſter to Hell!
Who can 't Diſſemble, Lewis th' Eleav'nth ſaid,
Can't Live: Craft ſhould not have this Craft betrayd.
What Blood in Paris-ſlaughter, Guiſe, did'ſt ſpill?
Thy Owne flow'd next: didſt thou not teach to kill?
Charles Loraine's Cardinal ſpeeches ſo fine
Did make, which part hee tooke None could divine!
Such Secrets to the Eye Botero brings,
Hee Audits the Eſtates of the World's Kings!
Paul the Third and Morone (they ſo compact)
At Rome and Trent, Volpone and Moſca act.
Rome's conclave's Vulcan's Forge, where make they doe
Inviſible nets for Bodies and Soules too.
In th' Orbe of Belgique Spaine ſee th' Excellence:
Marg'ret was ſtarre; Granville th' intelligence.
Spaine's Second Philip, Maſter of his Art,
His Wit and Pow'r ſometimes ſeemes to Out-ſtart.
The Indies, Philip, ſpread not like Thy roabe:
Art thou the New Horizon to the Globe?
How Philip in his Gallery views his Mappes!
Conſults! Intents in Myſtery hee wrappes!
Eſcurial's Hammon's Oracle in Sand:
What's wondrous, Philip, does in Deſert ſtand!
Perez flies Philip; Plots ſhews: reinvited
By Hopes, relents: Abroad's Fear'd; At Home Sleighted.
Philip, Day ends in Night: was Alva Lot,
Or Choiſe? Neglect of Cales too, was't a blot?
'T was Gondomar's great Aime, nor did hee ceaſe
In Project, to contrive all Chriſtians Peace.
Spalato moves, removes: H' had Time and Scope:
At laſt hee leaves his Conſcience for his Hope.
Strange Campanella would beſtow on Spaine
The World: but Hee'd bee Monarch of the Braine.
Rare B • ccaline, ſuch Policy th' haſt expreſs'd,
That th' haſt Out-Macchiavell'd Machiavel in jeſt.
Paul the Fift by his Venice-ſtrife Was ſham'd:
By him his Cardinals, to his Gaine were tam'd.
Ʋrban the Eight in Fear and Wit fell Sicke:
Hopes bandy: Plots appear: Hee's well. A Tricke!
Thrice ten times Barnevelt from Holland went
Embaſſadour; at laſt his Head they ſent.
The Rhene-Elector loſt much by Bavare
His friend: A kinder Cozen is not rare.
Nothing would Walſtein but a Crown content:
His Life was but in Hope and Treaſon ſpent.
Had not the Empire's Troubles Spaine halfe-maimd,
Richele • 's Wit had ne're been halfe ſo ſam'd.
Is Portugal a Cere-cloth on Spaine's ſide!
To Kill, or Vexe, or Cure, is it applied?
William the Firſt, whom Pride, Craft, Profit Sway'd,
Did England, but his Conſcience firſt, Invade.
Beau-Clerke a Saxon Lady weds: deep Art!
The Head is Norman: Saxon's now the Heart.
Steph'n a Choiſe Courtier grows King: and wrong'd Maud
Enforc'd Conſents: Can forc'd Conſent mend fraud?
The Spirits are Blood: Wit moves in fineſt Spirits:
By wit? by Blood, Steph'n thinks a Crowne hee merits.
D'Or • ton, thy Oracle (was Delphian ſtranger?)
Prompted bad Edward's death: yet thou ſcap'ſt danger!
How Craft does in the Cloſe it ſelfe oft mocke!
M • rtimer Great, But Bad, ſtoopes to the blocke!
Bullingebrooke's made a King: A great Pow'r choſe him:
In Death Fear Checks him: would his Fear depoſe him?
When the Sunne's Hid, yet the Eclipſe is ſeane:
Crooke-back's Deeds Obſcur'd Heav'n: yet knowne th' have been.
Morton fear'd his owne Head; yet ſo well us'd it,
That Buckingham's, and Crooke-backe's Life, excus'd it.
Does Warwick's death our Wiſeſt Henry taxe!
Crownes got by th' ſword, are oft kept by the Axe.
Had Wolſey Faults? H' had worth! know Thou Thy Lot:
Hee's Fame! Bee Thou content to bee Forgot.
Gard'ner had Art, Zeale, Rigour, Craft profound:
A Palſy-Prieſt, that was halfe-ſicke, halfe-ſound.
Walſingham's Wit, Slander or Ghueſſe did ſay,
Could through a Wall, Letter or Voice conveigh.
Raleigh, had thy brave Spirit been judg'd ſincere,
As thy wit Sharpe, th' had'ſt ſcap'd both Axe and Fear.
The moſt ſwell'd Politique's Vexation's Doubled,
To thinke, His Glory muſt bee All Unbubled!
The Grief the Subtleſt Traitour can't Expel,
Is't This, That hee can find no Crowne in Hell?
Ages to come ſhall bee Thy Juſt Adorer.
Truly Wiſe Albemarle, England's Reſtorer!
ALl things are Wonder ſince the World began:
The World's a Riddle, and the Meaning's Man!
All Men are not Alike: Some can Diſcerne,
And wiſely Teach Truth: Some can only Learne.
Happy the Sheep are, that Enjoy freſh ſprings:
Happier is Hee, the Sheep that thither Brings.
To make the Sheep the Sheapheard is a Mocke:
A Sheapheard then there muſt bee, as a Flock.
Wee're Kings and Prieſts; The King of Heav'n ſo makes us:
Wee're yet but Kings, as Prieſts: Man els miſtakes us.
Kings wee are in Conſcience, Subject but to God:
Not All men yet muſt ſcepter't: That were Odd.
Prieſts Men are heere in their Own Cloſets; where
All for themſelves their Hearts and Hands muſt reare.
All may not Raigne, neither all Prieſt it may;
The God of Wiſdome has giv'n no ſuch Sway.
To a Kings Counſailes All are not admitted:
By Wiſdome and High Favour Men are Fitted.
The Meaneſt Sheapheard ſhould have Age and Skill:
Els with the Flock it quickly will goe ill.
One Timothy the Goſpel once did ſpread:
But of an Age of Timothies wee ne're read.
A Taske and Honour 't is, but to Refine
The Body: Soules to Cure's a Taſke Divine.
A ſurer Copy of Truth's Worth's not had,
Then by the view of Men ſome Good, ſome Bad.
Philo a Jewiſh Prieſt Chriſtians Commends:
Shall Chriſtians bee worſe Jews to ſuch juſt friends?
To Moſes's Laws Philo would adde a grace:
Indeed hee takes the veile from Moſes's face.
Joſephus ſays, that Chriſt was more then Man;
Roſe the Third day: Was Hee not Chriſtian!
Joſephus did Veſpaſian's Raigne foretel,
In Propheſy, or Ghueſſe, hee did Excel.
If to th' Apoſtles, Canons doe belong,
The Queſtion'd Number does the Right ones wrong.
Growth's not the ſize of Grace: Judge not by th' Eye:
Saint Paul was but fow'r ſoote and a halfe high.
The Third Heav'n was beheld by Silent Paul:
Saint Denis ſaw it not: Yet would tell All!
Ignatius's Copies did they Credit need.
Vatican Manuſcripts ſmall ſaith would breed.
Juſtin Philoſophy in Life profeſs'd:
〈◊〉 Martyrdome a better hee Expreſs'd.
Wiſe Irenaeus ſoberly acute,
The Valentinian Madneſſe did refute.
Though Irenzus Hereſy O'rethrew;
In Phanſy yet hee Millenary grew.
Tertullian's Mantle is a Mantle, which
Shows his ſtricte Life; Halse hides his Wit, though Rich.
Tertullian, Thy Preſcriptions are a Guide:
Need'ſt Thou one? Is't from phanſy, or from Pride?
Clemens the Alexandrian needs muſt gaine yee,
With His Choiſe ſtore; Hee is but One, yet Many.
Minutius Felix is a Purer fire:
Hee's Wit ad Octo: Would hee yet riſe higher?
Julius Africanus writ a brief Story
Of a long time: The Worke's Loſt, not the Glory.
Origen without Death, by Art began
To bee a Saint; by being not a Man.
A Doubt it may bee, whither Origen writ
With greater Errour, or with greater Wit.
Victor the Pope more Buſy was, then Wiſe:
The Paſchal Quarrel hee did Overpriſe.
To Heav'n from Hell Chriſt's Way's without Compare:
Magique and Martyrdome, Cyprian's Lot's •• are!
Fond Manichie; what's Chief, only That's God?
Two Chiefes there are not: what's Supreme, is Odd.
Arnobius does with Learning and much Zeale
Hate •• gan Rites, if not too much reveale.
Lactantius happy Eloquence diſplays:
His Doctrine's not ſo happy, as his Phraſe.
Thou Epicycle of the Church Donatus, why
Art not contented with the Common Sky?
Donatus would his Church a new Arke make;
When as 't is Flood, not Arke! A ſtrange Miſtake!
The Gyant Arius ſaigne to Heav'n would Climbe,
To fight with God? Is hee not too Sublime.

'T was Pitty. Arius did Euſebius
• aint.
Taking the Sonne of God but for a Saint.
A Biſhop Athanaſius faign'd, whiles under
The Age of Wit: Sport was the Type of Wonder.
Moſt Chriſtian Athanaſius! Rare Projector
Of a ſtranger ſame; that was his God's Protector!

The Nice ••
Creed Chriſt's Godhead does profeſſe:
Were hee a Saviour els? Sure hee were Leſſe.
Saint Hilary, who in High Languague rowl'd,
Chriſtian and Biſhop's made, when hee is Old.
Of Baptiſme could vaine Mac • donius boaſt,
And for a Creature take the Holy Ghoſt?

Grave, Wiſe, Sweet Baſil,
〈◊〉 from fo • d deſires,
Was his Owne Mon • ſt'ry, his Thoughts the Friers.
Nyſſene, thy brother Baſil might bee ſame
For both; but Thou too Liv'ſt by thy Owne Name.
High Nazianzene and ſta •• ing! That 's thy D • e.
Harke how it Thunders! And it Lighte • s too!
Thy Ephiph •• ius from Hor • ſie's Grave.
Ambroſe, upon thy Infant-Lippes Bees ſate:
Still on the Hony of thy Lippes All Waite.
Conſtantinople-Fathers did Inherit
God's Grace, whiles they Profeſs'd the Holy Spirit •
True Muſique, Chryſoſtome, Thou waſt: The • pheare
Was ſaign'd: Bee Thou Still Tongue, wee'll ſtill bee Eare
Sharpe Jerom, to whoſe Critique Skill all ſeeke,

Tutor'd th' Old Church in
• a • i • , H • brew, Greek.
Great Auſtin! To bee Good, thou didſt not ſaint:
Thy Youth was Auſtia: but thy Age was Saint.
Auſtin, thou Chriſtian Hercules, ſame did'ſt winne
From Monſters! Thou ſtalt weare the Lion's Skinne.
In Britaine firſt, Pel • gius, ſawiſt the Sky?
Wee'll pray two, that in Britains thou maiſt Die.
Seleucian Baſil, like ſtrong fire's thy ſoule:
Whence ſtill doe mount Sounes of the Burning coule.
Noble Syneſius, d • licate as the Dove!
Downe's not ſo So • t: as Soft thou are as Love!
Salvian, art Over-righteous? Thy • ierce Zeale,
Wee Hope, miſtakes: thou would'ſt, whom thou would Heal •

Cyryll his Alexandri •
did and • dorne,

Whiles his Wit on Neſt • riu •
〈◊〉 juſt Scorne.
Theodoret from Cyril once diſſented:
Hee had not els ſo lear • edly r • pented.
Th' Epheſian Fathers did Neſtorius quell:
Hee thought Two Perſons did in one Chriſt dwell.
Two perſons can't make One: Two natures can
One Perſon make: Thus is Chriſt God and Man.
God is not Man; This would Confuſion make:
But into God, God did the Manhood take.
Truth and Saint Austin • r • ſper did defend;
A friend hee was to Truth 〈◊〉 to Truth's friend.
Vincentius Judge of trutly next to the Beſt •
Th' art Sentence, not Diſcourſe: Th' haſt all expreſs'd.
Leo unarm'd did turne-back Attila's Sword:
And arm'd with Truth quell'd Hereſy wit • 's Word.
Chriſt's Manhood Eu • ie ••• th' Abſurd denied:
Wee His; if Manhood bee by Reaſon tried.
Chriſt if not God, From Sinne Can no man quit:
By being Man, Chriſt to five Man, is Fitt.
Sidonius his wit, Muſe and Honour claime
Like-Right, to blazo • his 〈◊〉 happy Fame.
Chryſologus upon himſelfe did try
Practice: His Wit and his Devotion vie.
That didſt Chriſt's Godhead and his Grace Maintaine.
Time's Date from Diocleſian once begunne:
From Chriſt's Birth Dionyſius made it runne.
Job had fow'r Counſailours: but his Fiſt Friend,
Great Gregory, does on us his Counſaile ſpend.
Eve, Solomon and Iſid • re would know
All things: Doe they in Heav'n None Here below.
Poppy-braind Mahomet dream'd a Religion;
H' had need to bragge, ſure, of his holy pidgeon!
Peruſe the Various Labours of Old Bede;
You'll muſe, whither hee did more Write, or Read.
Wrong'd Da • aſcens did looſe his hand • betwixt
Errour and Truth he writ: the Man is Mixt.
Photius the Pope of Greece learnedly knowne
By Others Workes, makes Their Workes Halfe his Owne.
Bernard ſo happily imploi'd his thought,
Hee ſcarce had time to thinke of what was nought.
Fable and Malice is a Rabbine's Skill;
Their Rites excepted: the Reſt th' expreſſe ill.
Of Jewiſh Rites Ben-maimon does write true:
Happier Lyranus was a Chriſtian-Jew.
Galily's Glaſſe would in Heav'n find-out Ground:
In high Aquinos's Wit errour is ſound.
Scotus oppos'd Aquinas's Wit; nay more,
Head • d a Sect: yet Died at Thirty ſow'r.
Many built Bable's Tow'r; but Nim •• d's Fame:
Other mens Piles ſo raiſe T • ſtatus's Name.
Luther and Calvin Differd and Agreed:
Their Difference has made them both worſe ſpeed.
Beza, though Critiques ſtill Thy Taſke purſue
Thy Diligence and Copy will bee true.
Montanus in Tranſlating ſeldome trippes:
Rare Man! In Fear yet the Lord's Prayer hee Clippes,
Bellarmine pleads for Truth with Reaſons fit:
Againſt Truth hee brings Names and Seeming Wit.
Founder of th' Annels, whiles as partial blam'd,
May • 't thy worke bee Maſſa Corrupt • , Nam'd!
Though Method, Clearneſſe, and Compleatneſſe, call
Valentia Happy; Hee writ ſince the Fall.
Vaſquez is a deep Pioner; his Vau't
Hee makes with Art: yet ſometimes 't is at fau • t
•• arez his Curious Webbe ſo fine does ſpinne;
Ar • makes it weake; and oft it proves too Thinne.
S • cinus would an Archi • edes prove:
Stepp'd from the Church, the Church he would remove.
Poſa his Creed, Pope and Aquinus ſleighted!
In Spaine too! Hee was Over-Jeſuited!
Wiſe Martyr • , ſtout Cheminitius, and the Mild
Wh • taker, have Sathans Hopes much beguil'd.
Ch •• ier comes in the Beere: Hee ſ •• ornes to yield;
Conquers; and take the full ſpoile of the field.
Though ſome, of Earth j' th; Moone, doe vainly tell,
Elect Earth ſhall in Heav'n for ever dwell.
A Thouſand Beauties Solomon injoi'd.
Some will bee with theſe Thouſand Thoughts Imploy'd.
Father of Gifts, who to the Duſt did'ſt Give
Life, ſay to theſe my Meditations, Live.

div.head: Emendations.
div.p: NUmb. 45. l. 1. r. cold is n. 60. l. 1. r. feares, n. 82. l. 2. r. Nature's Art. n. 119. l. 1. r. ſhrimp. n. 231. l. 2. r. Byſantium. n. 255. l. 1. r. ſhow'd. n. 265. l. 1. r. Globes. n. 273. l. 1. r. joint-meale. n. 320. l. 1. r. ſhows. n. 321. l. i. r. twenty-two. n. 439. l. 1. r. inſtructs. n. 441. l. 1. r. and. n. 470. l. 2. r. it. ſelfe. n. 483. l. 2. r. what ſo e're rare. n. 504. l. 2. r. hi •• ſkill, n. 506. l. 1. r. Tamely indure n. 590. l. 2. r. Byetius. n. 625. l. 1. r. ſenators. n. 645. l. 1. r. reare; n. 745. l. 1. r. Apocryphal. n. 786. l. 1. r. eight. n. 819. l. 2. r. Court-taught. n. 876. l. 1. r. Boccaline. n. 886. l. 1. r. Maud. n. 888. l. 1. r. D'Orlton. l. 2. r. ſcap'dſt.
